pages.subdeck: Gun victim ... Thusha Kamaleswaran
pages.headline: Gang guilty of shooting five-year-old Thusha
pages.teaser: LITTLE Thusha Kamaleswaran was left paralysed for life after attack in shop
pages.articlebody:
GANG members who left a five-year-old girl paralysed after gunning her down in a shop have been found guilty of GBH.

Nathaniel Grant, Kazeem Kolawole and Anthony McCalla were convicted by a jury at the Old Bailey in London of causing grievous bodily harm to little Thusha Kamaleswaran.

She was shot by the thugs as she played in her aunt's shop in South London in March last year.

The nightmare scenes unfolded in March last year as the trio fired blindly into the Stockwell Food and Wine store.

A bullet hit Thusha in the chest and passed through the seventh vertebra of her spine, leaving her wheelchair-bound for life.

Shopper Roshan Selvakumar was shot in the face in the attack, and has been left with bullet fragments permanently lodged in his head.

Callous Grant, Kolawole and McCalla were looking for a rival gang member when Grant mindlessly opened fire into the shop.

Jurors were told that he would have been able to see Thusha as he fired his second shot.

Dramatic CCTV footage was also shown to the jury from inside the store, where Mr Selvakumar can be seen with blood pouring from his head and Thusha lies slumped on the floor.

The three defendants were found guilty of causing grievous bodily harm with intent to Thusha, now six, and Mr Selvakumar.

They were also convicted of attempted murder of their intended victim Roshaun Bryan.

Prosecutor Edward Brown QC told jurors: "The reality of this shooting may be that, whilst there was an intention to kill the suspected rival gang member, the gunman and his accomplices couldn't have cared less if someone else was shot too."

pages.subdeck: Injunction ... Tulisa Contostavlos
pages.headline: Tulisa ex: Sex tape her idea
pages.teaser: RAPPER MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  broke his silence over tape
pages.byline: By EMILY NASH and GARY O'SHEA
pages.articlebody:
THE former boyfriend of Tulisa Contostavlos broke his silence over their infamous sex tape yesterday and insisted it was HER idea.

Rapper MC Ultra  real name Justin Edwards  denied releasing the explicit footage, which shows the X Factor judge in an intimate moment with him.

He also backed a legal ban on the clip and said it should never have been made public.

In a statement read to London's High Court, Edwards, 28, said: "I am disgusted it has been, and regret ever allowing the claimant to persuade me that we should film ourselves."

He maintained he would not have published the clip  adding: "Simply because I would find it ungentlemanly. I was brought up better than that."

After the hearing, Edwards exclusively told The Sun: "I'm just relieved to have a chance to tell my side of the story.

"It can't happen soon enough. I've had to move out of my home and it's been a nightmare for my family.

"I just want this sorted out so I can move on with my life."

Last Friday Edwards was slapped with a £100,000 claim for damages for alleged breach of privacy and confidentiality by Tulisa, who accused him of leaking the six-minute video.

But yesterday he suggested the footage  published online last week  was filmed on the N-Dubz star's phone and denied he'd ever owned it.

His statement read: "I simply do not, and never have, possessed the film referred to."

Yet Tulisa's QC Desmond Browne told Mr Justice Tugendhat the singer had been "the victim of a vindictive act of betrayal by Mr Edwards  seemingly motivated by personal spite and financial greed".

He called the rapper's denial that he passed on the sex tape "hypocrisy" and "a deceitful representation of the position".

Tulisa, 23, won an injunction last week after the video appeared on the net for downloads.

In a preliminary hearing yesterday Mr Justice Tugendhat extended the ban on anyone using, publishing, communicating or disclosing the clip to any other person.

A date for the next hearing has not yet been set.

pages.subdeck: Scandal ... David Cameron
pages.headline: Chequers in the post
pages.teaser: MULTI-millionaire Tory donors wined and dined by David Cameron in No10 & Chequers
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor and EMILY ASHTON
pages.articlebody:
SEVENTEEN multi-millionaire Tory donors have been wined and dined by David Cameron in No 10 and Chequers since he became PM, most of them secretly, it emerged last night.

The business and City fat cats handed over a total £23million to boost Conservative coffers.

The party was forced to reveal the embarrassing list as the cash for access scandal engulfing the PM deepened.

In another bruising day for Mr Cameron, Downing Street was pushed into a series of embarrassing U-turns to distance itself from shamed former treasurer Peter Cruddas, who was sacked two days ago.

He was caught by Sunday Times undercover reporters saying big donors to the party could buy time with the PM as well as influence over Government policies.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Cameron used his official country mansion Chequers and No 10 to glad-hand loaded supporters. Chancellor George Osborne also revealed that three Tory donors visited his residence at Dorneywood, Bucks.

They were Lord Feldman, Lord Wolfson and Howard Leigh. All are long-standing friends and visited in a personal capacity.

Only 24 hours earlier, No 10 had insisted the public had NO right to know who the Premier invited to his flat because it was private.

But by 6pm yesterday, the Tories had listed every private lunch or dinner the PM had with donors who gave over £50,000. The occasions include:

A "thank you" dinner in the state rooms of No 10 for party donors after the General Election win in July 2010.

Three private dinners with him and wife Samantha in his No 10 flat between February 2011 and February 2012.

Three lunches at Chequers over the last two years.

In a bid to put the scandal behind him, Mr Cameron again called the Cruddas bragging "completely unacceptable". The PM insisted: "None of these dinners were fundraising dinners and none were paid for by the taxpayer. I have known most of those attending for many years. Peter Cruddas has never recommended anyone to come to dinner in the flat."

Mr Cameron also promised that from now the Tories will publish details of meals attended by donors in Downing Street and Chequers.

The PM also urged Labour leader Ed Miliband to agree a cap on individual political donations of £50,000. He said: "We could take the big money out of politics, once and for all."

In another U-turn, the Tories appointed lawyer and Tory peer Lord Gold to lead an internal party inquiry. The PM's initial choice, Tory chairman and close pal Lord Feldman, was met with howls of derision.

Labour insisted nothing short of a full independent inquiry would do.

Despite denials that donors influenced policy, it emerged yesterday that a big giver wrote a major policy document at No 10's request. Venture capitalist Adrian Beecroft, who gave £593,000 to the party, drew up plans to remove some workers' rights.

Asked whether PM will entertain donors in his private flat in future, a close aide said: "I suspect that there won't be that many. But there's nothing wrong with the PM meeting people who have donated to the party."

In another hurried move, the Government tried to restart stalled cross-party talks on party funding.

Tory MP Matthew Hancock last night asked ex-PMs Tony Blair and Gordon Brown to reveal Labour donors who dined at No 10 and Chequers.

By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor

THINK you've heard the cash for access story before?

You have. Three times this year in one shape or form, dozens over the last decade, thousands over the previous century.

Neither is big money sleaze a Tory disease. Labour and the Lib Dems are in it up to their necks.

So why do British politicians keep on making the same mistakes over and over again?

Despite all their rhetoric about the need for change, it never comes. They do nothing because they're scared nobody likes them.

A cap on big donations  be they from businessmen, unions or charities  would mean parties have to rely on small donations from ordinary people.

Every party secretly fears there are far too few left who trust politicians enough to hand over their hard-earned pennies and stop the parties going bust.

They are right, and it's a vicious circle. Because with every fresh cash for access scandal, the number dwindles even further.

pages.subdeck: WHO, ME? ... Michael Carrick protests his innocence - but not even Fergie was convinced
pages.headline: We Rood our luck
pages.teaser: WAYNE ROONEY'S winner put Man United top  but even Fergie admitted they got lucky
pages.articlebody:
WAYNE ROONEY'S winner lifted Manchester United back to the top of the table  but even boss Alex Ferguson admitted they got lucky.

Fulham should have been awarded a late penalty when Michael Carrick fouled sub Danny Murphy.

Boss Alex Ferguson said: "Yes, Michael tapped their player's heel and they had a good claim.

"The ref was lenient also in the first half when we should have had a penalty for handball. Maybe the ref was thinking about that."

Fulham boss Martin Jol said: "We expected a penalty to be given but it takes a very brave referee to give one against United at Old Trafford.

"This isn't the first time, especially not for me.

"Everyone in the stadium expected a penalty and the ref would have had to send Carrick off.

"We could have shocked them, they looked very nervous."

Ferguson admitted: "Fulham finished the game very strongly and caught us out on the counter-attack.

"We started giving the ball away and it was disappointing not to finish them off.

"But we played well for 60 minutes and it's a very good win for us.

"Over the years I don't know how many times I've said 1-0 is a great result. It means championship form."

pages.subdeck: Reunion ... mum Rose Barwuah and Manchester City striker Mario Balotelli
pages.headline: Balotelli mum's reunion joy
pages.teaser: MOTHER of the Man City ace says: 'I am happy to see him and he is happy to see me'
pages.byline: By JANE ATKINSON and NICK PISA
pages.articlebody:
THE MUM of Man City ace Mario Balotelli last night told of her joy at being reunited after giving him up as a child.

Relieved Rose Barwuah, 46, added: "I am happy to see him and he is happy to see me."

The Sun told on Sunday how Rose moved from Italy to the tough estate featured in TV's Shameless to be near the striker, 21, in the hope of rekindling their relationship.

Her £120,000-a-week son  who she handed to a rich foster family when he was two  now often shows up in his white Bentley GT at her £550-a-month rented terrace.

Rose said: "Mario has been over to see me a few times, but he doesn't want people to know I'm here. We don't see each other all the time as he has his life and I have mine.

"He's a private person and it's still early days." She added: "I haven't even been to watch him play football here yet, but I'm very proud of him. I'm thrilled, overjoyed to be here."

Rose and daughter Angel, 13, moved to Manchester's Wythenshawe area just before Christmas. Angel now goes to a local school.

Nineteen years ago in Italy, she and hubby Thomas were advised to hand Mario to foster parents  the Balotellis.

The couple were then living in a tiny flat in Brescia  and claimed the Balotellis turned Mario against them.

pages.subdeck: Caged ... student Liam Stacey has been jailed for 56 days
pages.headline: Muamba Twitter troll is jailed
pages.teaser: STUDENT Liam Stacey was jailed for 56 days after inciting racial hatred conviction
pages.articlebody:
A TWITTER troll who mocked stricken footballer Fabrice Muamba after he collapsed on the pitch has been jailed for 56 days.

Liam Stacey, 21, admitted inciting racial hatred. He posted a string of vile comments on the microblogging site as medics desperately fought to save the player's life.

Muamba, 23, suffered a heart attack on March 17 as his Bolton Wanderers team took on Spurs in the FA Cup.

Stacey, a Swansea University biology student, was caught after police were swamped with complaints about his remarks.

The first of his messages began with "LOL. **** Muamba. He's dead!!!"

Other Twitter users bombarded the student with criticism following his sick post. Stacey replied with a number of hateful racist comments.

Last week he admitted inciting racial hatred when he appeared at Swansea Magistrates' Court.

He was released on conditional bail but warned that all options would be considered at his sentencing today.

The maximum possible sentence was seven years.

Stacey's lawyer Gareth Jones said that his client had drunk eight pints before his rant.

He said: "He is completely ashamed of his behaviour that evening.

"On the night in question his comments were vile, he admits that."

He added that Stacey was actually "a kind and caring person", who felt "genuine remorse".

Muamba has made an incredible recovery since his heart attack ten days ago and was well enough to watch Match Of The Day over the weekend.

Today his team mates Jussi Jaaskelainen, Steve Davis, Zat Knight and David Wheater visited him at his London hospital.

The morale-boosting trip came before tonight's replay of the quarter-final against Spurs, which was abandoned after Muamba's collapse.

pages.subdeck: So brave ... Captain Lisa Head
pages.headline: Lisa inquest praises bravery
pages.teaser: CAPTAIN Lisa Head was only second woman killed while serving in Afghanistan
pages.articlebody:
A FEARLESS bomb disposal expert died after she returned to the scene of an explosion to help secure a village.

Captain Lisa Head, 29, became only the second female member of our Armed Forces in Afghanistan to be killed in nearly a decade.

Capt Head  of 11 Explosive Ordnance Disposal Regiment, the Royal Logistic Corps  had been blown off her feet when an undetected IED in an alley partially detonated under her foot on April 18 last year.

She was knocked to the ground but got up and, after gathering her courage, returned to the alley in Padaka, Helmand, where she was then blown up by a booby trap.

An inquest held at Bradford Coroner's Court heard how her unit did a similar job to that portrayed in Oscar-winning movie The Hurt Locker.

And Capt Head's comrade Corporal Adam Tucker told the court about her final moments, saying she had made safe one bomb before a second one knocked her off her feet.

He said she returned to their vehicle, smoked "a few cigarettes and made light of it".

Cpl Tucker added: "Being the stubborn Yorkshire woman that she was, she said she was quite happy to continue and went back down the alley."

While defusing a second IED, she knelt down and triggered a third five kilogram device that blew off both her legs, right arm and the fingers on her left hand.

Cpl Tucker and colleagues raced down the alley, applied emergency dressings and called in a helicopter.

Capt Head of Huddersfield, West Yorks, was taken to hospital at Camp Bastion, then flown to the Queen Elizabeth military hospital in Birmingham, where she died on April 19.

Recording a verdict of unlawful killing, Bradford Coroner Prof Paul Marks paid tribute to the soldier.

He said: "I cannot praise too highly the courage of Lisa Head."

pages.subdeck: Jailed ... David Bryant
pages.headline: Kidnap paedo jailed after 30 yrs
pages.teaser: GRANDFATHER David Bryant was caught after escaping justice for three decades
pages.articlebody:
A VILE paedophile who escaped justice for three decades has been jailed for 16 years.

Grandfather David Bryant, 65, snatched four little girls in the 1980s and 1990s.

He then sexually abused them before dumping them back on the street.

Bryant, from Ulverston, Cumbria, said he felt "a sense of grievance" having been caught so long after his sick offences.

He was sentenced today at Newcastle Crown Court for terrifying kidnap and sex attacks on four victims in Hampshire and Tyneside.

Judge James Goss, the Recorder of Newcastle, said: "All your victims were very young girls aged five or under.

"There was a distinct pattern to your offences.

"In each case you approached your victim near to where you were working at the time, took them to a place of privacy where you sexually assaulted them."

In the first case in the early 1980s, he grabbed a girl aged five who was playing outside her Hampshire home.

She was found by a couple later, but crucially Bryant had left DNA evidence on her.

The breakthrough came after police arrested one of his brothers on suspicion of an unrelated offence.

Cops then eliminated Bryant's other male relatives from the enquiry until they were left with only him.

His DNA was linked to all four cases and he was charged.

Outside court, Detective Chief Inspector Steve Binks said: "For 30 years, Bryant left these victims and their families traumatised by his despicable actions and has shown absolutely no remorse.

"I can't praise the families and victims enough for their support and strength through this long and traumatic ordeal.

"Our officers and our colleagues in Hampshire Police worked tirelessly to get this man behind bars and today we welcome the fact justice has finally been done.

"Our investigation led us to presenting evidence to Bryant, including a positive DNA match, which left him unable to deny his heinous crimes any longer."

pages.subdeck: Cloud ... Elgin field rig
pages.headline: 'Well from hell' gas leak fears
pages.teaser: A DEVASTATING gas leak at a "well from hell" sparked a North Sea evacuation today - and fears of an environmental disaster
pages.articlebody:
A DEVASTATING gas leak sparked a North Sea evacuation today  and fears of an environmental disaster.

French company Total confirmed gas was still pouring out of its Elgin field 140 miles off the Scottish coast.

Workers claimed the sea beneath their rig was "bubbling"  while one expert dubbed it the "well from hell".

Coastguards declared a two-mile air and sea exclusion zone as a cloud of explosive natural gas appeared in the sky.

And Total flew in experts used by BP to battle its Gulf of Mexico spill two years ago.

Total's health and safety manager David Hainsworth admitted the leak could go on for "a significant period of time" after it was first spotted on Sunday.

He added a new well may have to be drilled to tackle the problem  but that could take MONTHS.

Stunned environmentalists warned the problem would only get "bigger and bigger".

Frederic Hauge, of Norwegian oil consultants Bellona, said: "This is the well from hell. The problem is out of control.

"They saw the sea bubbling with gas under the platform. This is quite shocking."

Shell was forced to evacuate workers from two nearby platforms amid reports of a six-mile sheen of gas condensate on the water.

Total's Elgin and nearby Franklin fields produce the equivalent of 230,000 barrels of gas a day. The Elgin field lies four miles beneath the sea bed.

With production shut down, wholesale gas prices leapt 4 per cent, threatening another rise in household gas bills.

Jake Molloy, regional organiser of the OILC union said: "If the reports we are getting from people coming off the installation are accurate, this is extremely serious.

"It's an extremely dangerous situation especially if it's volatile explosive gas or potentially poisonous gas in the case of hydrogen sulphide."

The chaos sparked memories of the Gulf of Mexico disaster that almost pushed BP out of business.

Last week, Chancellor George Osborne heralded a new dawn of deepwater exploration in the Shetlands by offering companies such as Total a £3billion tax break.

pages.subdeck: Victims ... William Mapstone and Liaquat Ali
pages.headline: M5 crash victims named as tributes flow in
pages.teaser: LORRY driver William Mapstone and Liaquat Ali were killed in smash in Midlands
pages.articlebody:
A DRIVER who was killed when his lorry crashed into the back of a stationary bus on the M5 has been named.

William Mapstone, 65, from Wells, Somerset, died shortly after 9pm on Saturday at a Birmingham hospital.

The crash killed bus passenger Liaquat Ali, 35  a dad of three  and left another in a critical condition.

Mr Ali was confirmed dead at the scene of the crash near junction three of the M5 at Halesowen.

The driver of the bus remains on bail after being arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving.

The vehicle is reported to have broken down amid thick fog in a live lane of the M5 near Frankley Services.

Mr Mapstone's family paid tribute to him today.

They said in a statement: "Our dad was tragically taken away from us while doing the job he so very much loved.

"We would very much like to thank the people who helped both us and Dad through such a tragic time, including all the emergency services that attended the scene to help Dad on the motorway to try and save him."

Mr Ali's family paid tribute to "a loving husband" and father.

They said: "Liaquat was the loving husband of Fozia Shaheen and was the father of two sons and a daughter  Shafqat Ali, aged nine, Mohammed Owais Ali, aged two, and Kashish Eman, aged six.

"He will be dearly missed by his family and friends and also leaves behind three brothers."

pages.subdeck: Dip ... Hollie Blake, 18, paddles in West Wittering, West Sussex
pages.headline: Britain hotter than Bermuda
pages.teaser: TEMPERATURES expected to soar tomorrow to 23C -hotter than Bermuda
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN is set to bask is temperatures of more than 23°C (73°F) tomorrow  making it hotter than Turkey, Portugal and Bermuda.

Cherry blossoms have appeared on trees four weeks early thanks to the hot weather. And today sun-seeking Brits spent the day on the beach to make the most of the balmy end to March before temperatures fall at the weekend for the start of the Easter holidays.

Bikini-clad sunbathers enjoyed soaking up the rays in Langland Bay near Swansea, South Wales, West Wittering in West Sussex, and St Austell, Cornwall.

This year's record UK temperature was only set on Monday when temperatures hit 23.2°C at Cromdale in the Highlands.

Met Office forecaster Sarah Holland said: "It is very mild and a nice change for March.

"In the next couple of days the temperatures will be above average and dry and sunny.

"Later in the week the temperatures will be in the high teens, with more cloud and changeable weather.

"The weekend will see a return to more normal temperatures for this time of year. They will still be in double figures but people will notice the change."

pages.subdeck: Busker to beauty queen ... Miss England contestant Lena Walker
pages.headline: From busker to beauty queen
pages.teaser: ENCOURAGEMENT from passers-by led to teenager entering beauty pageant
pages.articlebody:
A STUNNING busker has turned Miss England hopeful after her fans encouraged her to enter the beauty pageant.

Lena Walker took to the streets of her home city of Leicester with her guitar to raise money for charity.

But the 17-year-old was surprised when scores of people approached her to praise her music  and her good looks.

The pretty student said: "I decided to give busking a go  but never expected the reaction I got.

"Loads of people were coming up to me and commenting on my music, but also my looks."

After entering the Miss England contest, she battled through several rounds to make the national finals.

She added: "I've always been a down-to-earth girl, so had never really considered putting myself in to be judged on my looks.

"But after my family and friends said I should do it, and with the confidence of all the comments from the public, I thought why not."

And after beating off competition from 22 other girls, she will now compete in the Miss England final in Leicester on June 26.

Lena said: "I don't think it has really hit me that I've made it into the last 60 girls left from the whole UK.

"I'm sure it will sink in once I'm on that stage."

And she says she's looking forward to competing in front of her home crowd.

She said: "Hopefully my down-to-earth nature will shine through and win me some support.

"I'll have plenty of family and friends there, what with it being held in my home town.

"It could be a struggle fitting them all in!"

If things don't work out, Lena may still have a career in music  as she raised a whopping £35 an hour while busking

But the big-hearted student donated the cash she raised to charities.

She added: "The public have been very generous whenever I have put myself on a limb and taken to the streets to play my music.

"I play a lot of my own stuff that I write, but also play a few crowd-pleasers like David Guetta, Jessie J and Foster The People.

"On a good day I've made £35 an hour and would stay for a couple of hours at least.

"It isn't all glamour though. I'd often get back from a session busking and your fingers would be numb thanks to the cold."

pages.subdeck: Mischievous ... Willow and owner Fran
pages.headline: Woman dismantles car to find missing hamster
pages.teaser: MECHANICS remove seats, panels and doors to find tiny Willow who was stuck inside
pages.articlebody:
A WOMAN was forced to have her entire car dismantled after her brand new pet hamster escaped inside it on the way home from the shop.

Student Fran Elkington, 33, had just picked up little Willow and was on her 15-minute drive home when the critter vanished from her cardboard box.

But after trying everything to find the hamster, Fran had to take her car to mechanics who spent 90 minutes removing the seats, back panels and even the DOORS from her VW Beetle before finding Willow nestled in a gap near the boot.

Fran, from Letchworth, Herts, refused to use the car for five days as she desperately tried to locate the hamster.

And she said she was petrified Willow would either perish  or EAT the inside of her car as she noticed her upholstery was being slowly nibbled away.

She said: "I tried everything to get her out, even a humane rat trap, but after five days drastic action had to be taken.

"I couldn't just let her live in my car and destroy it from the inside out.

"I put food down because I didn't want her to starve to death, and as the days went on the food and water was disappearing so I knew she was in there somewhere, munching away.

"She shredded the upholstery all around her to make a nest, eventually we found a trail that led behind the back seat and under the floor of the boot.

"It's such a girlie embarrassing thing to have to go to a garage with but she was just too clever for me.

"It took three mechanics an hour and a half to get her out but they were great, they didn't charge me a penny in the end because they were laughing too hard."

Big-hearted mechanic Graham Day  who agreed to waive the £300 fee for the job and put Fran's car back together for free  said: "I had to coax her out of her new home - she seemed to be pretty happy there."

pages.subdeck: Barred ... transgender model Jenna Talackova, right
pages.headline: Aspiring Miss Universe axed for being born a man
pages.teaser: TRANSGENDER model Jenna Talackova axed after show chiefs discover she was a man
pages.articlebody:
A MISS Universe hopeful has been booted out after pageant bosses discovered she used to be a MAN.

Transgender model Jenna Talackova, 23, was barred from the Canadian round of the contest and is claiming discrimination.

National director Denis Davila said only girls "naturally born female" were allowed, adding: "We embrace diversity. Just because she can't compete doesn't mean we stopped loving her."

Her exit sparked a wave of support with more than 25,000 people signing an online petition calling for her reinstatement.

Talackova vowed to fight the move, made only after she made it to the finals of Miss Vancouver.

She first considered herself female aged four and began hormone therapy at 14. At 19 she went under the knife and had gender reassignment to complete her transformation.

She said: "I will look to turn this situation into a positive so that other people in a similar situation are not discriminated against in the future."

Contest chiefs issued a statement saying she was eliminated "because she did not meet the requirements to compete despite having stated otherwise on her entry form".

Davila maintained every contestant must be a "naturally born female" and Talackova had been "dishonest".

He said: "There is no discrimination here at all. We have a set of rules that we must enforce.

"The rules are very clear and there's no way we can go back on it."

pages.subdeck: Wager ... John Adam lost a bet with Welsh pal James Griffiths and had to get a Wales tattoo
pages.headline: Tatt's friendship for you
pages.teaser: ENGLISHMAN loses bet with Welsh rugby pal and gets Wales tattoo inked on his back
pages.articlebody:
A PROUD Englishman has paid the ultimate price for losing a bet with a Welshman  by getting a Wales tattoo on his back.

John Adam, 22, made a wager with his rugby-loving pal James Griffiths that England would win the Six Nations.

Welsh James, 21, pledged he would get an English Rose tattoo if England won  as long as John did the same but with a Wales inking.

And when Wales swept to Grand Slam glory it was unlucky John who had to bite the bullet.

Yesterday he had the six-inch Prince of Wales' feathers inked on to his back.

John said: "It looks nice, it's just a shame I'm English.

"It would be a great tattoo for a Welshman."

John  who is a student at the University of Glamorgan with James  was working at the Millennium Stadium bar when he realised he had lost the bet.

He said: "I heard the huge roar at the end of the game I knew that I was going to have to go through with it.

"I literally curled up with my head in my hands and asked myself what on earth was I thinking."

Victorious James went with John to the studio and paid for his mate's £35 tatt.

The final year students have been friends since fresher's week and now live together.

James said: "John makes stupid bets all the time but this is the first time it's ever led to a tattoo.

"I asked him what hurts more, having the tattoo done or your wounded pride.

"It would have been a great tattoo if he wanted it, unfortunately he didn't.

"Now he's stuck with it for ever."

John had the bright red design etched on him during an hour long session at a tattoo studio in Treforest.

Parlour boss Dan Harris, 31, said: "We get a lot of sports fans getting commemorative tattoos but usually it's for their own team.

"In 20 years his kids will probably ask him why he's got that tattoo when he's English.

"And he's going to have to tell them it's because Wales have a better rugby team."

pages.subdeck: Frightening scene ... Camilla points gun
pages.headline: Stick 'em up!
pages.teaser: BUT don't worry it was only the Duchess playing around with a replica pistol from The Killing
pages.articlebody:
THE Duchess of Cornwall confessed to being "addicted" to crime drama The Killing as she posed with a gun on the set of the Danish hit show today.

Camilla had requested a trip to see filming in a scrapyard outside Copenhagen, Denmark, on the final day of her eight-day tour of Scandinavia with the Prince of Wales.

The Duchess, who borrowed show star Sofie Grabol's weapon, confessed: "I'm an addict. I'm so excited by this."

It came after Charles revealed that his wife had introduced him to the detective show.

But while she got a sneak peek at the latest series, he went to a nearby housing estate.

Series creator Soren Sveistrup had met the couple yesterday at a reception hosted by the British ambassador.

He said: "Royalty is not the kind of audience you would expect. Prince Charles told me that it was Camilla who introduced him to The Killing.

"He said it was one of the only things they could agree on seeing together."

The Duchess appeared fascinated by the replica gun used by actress Sofie, who plays detective Sarah Lund.

And she asked if it was REAL.

Grabol told her: "It is just a toy gun. It weighs nothing."

As Camilla waved it around, she joked: "It was me all along."

Sarah Lund is known for her Faroe Island knitwear and Camilla was given her very own classic jumper.

Sofie said: "I think it is really surreal. But it's lovely that she wanted to come here.

"I told her last night to wear flat shoes. This is not really an inviting place for a royal visit.

"When I met the Duchess she was just so lovely to talk to."

Camilla also met actor Nikolaj Kaas, who plays a secret service agent working with Lund.

Referring to the fact two of Lund's previous colleagues have been killed in the first two series, the Duchess told him: "I hope we are going to see you again.

"I hope you don't go the same way as the others."

pages.subdeck: Murderer ... Mohammed Merah
pages.headline: Massacre footage shot by Toulouse killer emerges
pages.teaser: FOOTAGE made by murderer was posted to a TV station the day before he was killed
pages.articlebody:
HORRIFIC footage of the shootings carried out by Toulouse terrorist Mohammed Merah has emerged in France.

The video, which was released to broadcaster Al Jazeera, comes after investigators confirmed the serial killer wore a small camera when he murdered a Rabbi, his two children and a schoolgirl.

A week earlier he had filmed his killings of three French soldiers who had fought in Afghanistan.

The footage is said to have been edited into a sickening montage of the murders to a soundtrack of Islamic war songs.

It was sent in a package post-dated March 21  the day before Merah, 23, was shot dead by police following a siege at his home.

The timing raised fears he may have had an accomplice who mailed the package.

Merah's brother Abdelkader, 29, appeared before an anti-terror judge in Paris on Sunday. He has been charged with complicity in murder.

He was remanded in custody after he told police interrogators that he was "very proud" of his brother's actions.

Security chiefs in Paris think the brothers were involved with two local Islamist organisations, Forsane Alizza and a more militant network called Jund al-Khalifah.

The latter is an al-Qaeda splinter group, which says it worked with someone called Youssef the Frenchman.

Investigators are probing whether this was a name used by Merah.

pages.subdeck: Dial have one ... iRetrofone
pages.headline: Retro phone is a call idea
pages.teaser: MISS the old dialler phones of years ago? Now you can turn your iPhone into one...
pages.articlebody:
FANS of the iPhone can turn back time with this latest accessory which transforms a trendy mobile into an old-fashioned rotary dial machine.

The £123 iRetrofone has a dock for the owner's smartphone, then they can speak through the chunky antique receiver.

You can even download an App to give your dialling the authentic clicking sound - and set it to belt out an old-style ringtone of the brrrrrrrrring brrrrrrrrrrrring variety.

American designer Scott Freeland, 43, made the first iRetrofone for his studio but then realised it would have broader appeal.

He said: "My goal was to fuse art with function.

"I remembered the rotary phone from my childhood and the iRetrofone brings back nostalgic memories of life before the iPhone."

pages.headline: Is 4in Beyoncé the smallest dog?
pages.teaser: LITTLE Dachsund mix pooch from California is the size of an iPhone and fits into a spoon
pages.articlebody:
A PUPPY named Beyoncé could be the world's smallest dog  measuring barely 4in.

The tiny pooch was so small when she was born she fit into a spoon.

And at 19 days old her teensy body is barely the size of an iPhone.

Animal rescuers said the female Dachshund mix was part of a litter of five, born on March 8.

She was delivered at the Grace Foundation in El Dorado Hills, California, after her pregnant mum Casey was picked up from the streets.

She was the last one to come out and did not have a heartbeat at first. Vets managed to revive her through chest compressions and mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.

After that she had to be bottle-fed every hour because he mouth was too small to feed normally.

The foundation has submitted an application to Guinness World Records for the crown of world's smallest dog.

It'll surely be ruff justice if she misses out on the title.

pages.subdeck: Cup for it ... entrant at 2012 Sport Stacking competition
pages.headline: Cup competition is stacks of fun
pages.teaser: JAPANESE entrants battle to be fastest to make pyramid from plastic cups
pages.articlebody:
QUICK-FINGERED cup-stackers were given the chance to show off their incredible skills at the 2012 Sport Stacking competition in Tokyo.

More than 100 people battled it out yesterday to find who could assemble 12 specially-designed plastic cups into a pyramid in the shortest time.

Participants are permitted to take part solo, in team relays, or even with a partner  with each of the pair only allowed to use one hand.

And while it might not seem like the most interesting sport, young and old alike told how addictive they found stacking cups.

Shuuji Hirasaki, 53, who took part in a parent-child team with his 10-year-old son Ryouya, explained: "Once I actually tried it, it's really quite interesting and now I'm kind of hooked."

At 83, Senzaburo Kunimatsu was 79 years older than the youngest entrant  but still said he enjoyed the contest.

He explained: "I'm just doing it to help prevent getting old. I don't really worry about setting a record."

Teenager Sota Takamori was crowned the winner at the end of the day, with an blistering time of just 1.93 seconds for assembling the simplest version of the pyramid.

He has previously won the competition four times.

This year's victory qualifies him to take part in the World Stacking Championships this April in Butzbach, Germany.

pages.subdeck: Recycled art ... rhinoceros-type creature
pages.headline: Rubber sculptures are the wheel deal
pages.teaser: HUGE models of animals are made by moulding together rubber collected from wheels
pages.articlebody:
THIS artist will need to take a brake  after assembling these amazing sculptures from nothing but used tyres.

Imaginative Yong Ho Ji salvages rubber for his designs from old cars he finds at scrap yards.

He then spends months cutting each tyre into thin strips before moulding them together into models of animals, with some standing more than 5ft tall.

One of his scary sculptures is a huge rhinoceros-type beast, complete with an enormous horn.

Another of his creations is a huge lion rearing up on its hind legs, while one sculpture is a Minotaur, a creature from ancient Greek myth.

Yong Ho, from Korea, told how he had the idea of making models from tyres after visiting his local scrap yard to find parts for his car.

He explained: "Because of their rubbery nature, tyres can be cut, bent, and manipulated into many different forms and shapes. The flexibility and the strength of tyres drew me to them.

"Every artist has their own medium they work best in and for me it's definitely old tyres. You could say I'm burning rubber."

He uses up to 50 different tyres on a single sculpture, with each artwork taking anywhere from a few weeks to several months to finish.

He added: "Many people tell me that they are frightened by my works. But the truth is that our society is already familiar with freakish things.

"Take genetic engineering and environmental pollution for example.

"There have been cases where eating genetically modified food could have caused strange, unexplainable diseases: babies born with two heads, and a lab mouse with a human ear growing on its back."

pages.headline: It's Star Guitars
pages.teaser: HANDY Tom Bingham spends months turning normal guitars into Star Wars space ships
pages.articlebody:
MUSIC fan Tom Bingham does a brilliant Han Solo  on his collection of Star Wars-themed guitars.

The 64-year-old spends up to three months creating his masterpieces using bits of scrap bought from car boot sales.

So far he's amassed a collection of more than 20 instruments over the past decade  including an electric guitar in the style of a Millennium Falcon.

Retired printer Tom, from Corby, Northants, said: "I like Star Wars and I like other sci-fi stuff too.

"I saw a picture of a Millennium Falcon on the internet years ago and did my own version.

"I use a replica and attach a neck to it. With the Falcon I even put flashing LED lights in the back.

"It lights up blue in the dark, it gives it a hyperdrive look. The kids love it.

"The important thing is you have to make the body very rigid l I had to take the Millennium Falcon kits apart to their 140 odd pieces and rebuild it so it supports the neck I attach it to.

"It isn't easy and took hours painstakingly building it every day."

The married dad of two's other wacky creations include a vinyl record guitar, chessboard guitar and a cricket bat guitar  based on a Captain Sensible LP cover from 1982.

Another creation, a "multi-purpose Busker CBG" guitar, has an amplifier built in as well as a zippo lighter, a pick holder, a bottle opener, a vanity mirror, a clock, a penny whistle and 12in cigar "for when the busker hits the big time".

Tom added: "I originally started making cigar box guitars but I got bored. Now I just make them out of anything.

"I've got a bit of an obsession with it now, it's my hobby, one thing just leads to another."

Despite having offers for his quirky creations from as far away as Russia and the US the retired screen printer insists his guitars are not for sale.

He said: "I'm not tempted by any offers of money."

pages.subdeck: Pay more ... Royal Mail raises first and second class stamps by up to 39 per cent
pages.headline: Stamp prices to rise by up to 39%
pages.teaser: UNIONS say inflation-busting rises are the price paid for expected privatisation
pages.articlebody:
ROYAL Mail is raising the price of stamps by an inflation-busting 39 per cent.

Both first and second class stamps will go up 14p from April 30 to 60p and 50p.

That's a 30 per cent rise for first class and 39 per cent hike for second.

Inflation was 3.4 per cent last month according to the Consumer Prices index.

Robert Hammond, of Consumer Focus, said: "This is not great news for consumers. I doubt anyone is going to think about the challenges facing Royal Mail when they are paying 60p for a first class stamp.

"Unfortunately, the economics of Royal Mail meant that something had to give to maintain the universal service obligation.

"Our research suggests that for some customers there is a fine line between being willing to pay more and deciding to walk away from using the postal service."

Royal Mail defended the move saying it was being squeezed by competition and electronic communications.

The number of letters posted every day is down from 84million six years ago to 59million today.

It has lost £1billion over the last four years.

Cheapest

Ofcom has given Royal Mail the freedom to set its own prices but it said second class stamps will still be the cheapest in Europe. Their cost will be capped at 55p  linked to inflation  over the next seven years.

The cost of posting large letters will increase from 75p to 90p for first class and 58p to 69p for second class.

A Department for Business spokesman said: "Ministers are clear that the top priority is to protect the universal service on which people rely.

"Indeed we have enshrined in law the 'six day a week, one price goes anywhere service' and given Ofcom the duty of protecting that service.

"But this service comes at a cost, and its provider, Royal Mail, needs to be financially viable."

Around five million people on pension credit and employment and support allowance or incapacity benefit will be eligible for a Christmas scheme which will make stamps available at the old prices.

Billy Hayes, general secretary of the Communication Workers Union, said: "Today's announcement from Ofcom is the natural progression towards full competition and privatisation of postal services where customers pay more and efficiencies are sought in the interests of profit not services.

"Those people who baulk at the idea of stamp price rises should understand that it comes directly from Government decisions to privatise this industry - just as we've seen massive price increases in train travel under privatisation."

pages.subdeck: So brave ... Captain Lisa Head
pages.headline: Lisa inquest praises bravery
pages.teaser: CAPTAIN Lisa Head was only second woman killed while serving in Afghanistan
pages.articlebody:
A FEARLESS bomb disposal expert died after she returned to the scene of an explosion to help secure a village.

Captain Lisa Head, 29, became only the second female member of our Armed Forces in Afghanistan to be killed in nearly a decade.

Capt Head  of 11 Explosive Ordnance Disposal Regiment, the Royal Logistic Corps  had been blown off her feet when an undetected IED in an alley partially detonated under her foot on April 18 last year.

She was knocked to the ground but got up and, after gathering her courage, returned to the alley in Padaka, Helmand, where she was then blown up by a booby trap.

An inquest held at Bradford Coroner's Court heard how her unit did a similar job to that portrayed in Oscar-winning movie The Hurt Locker.

And Capt Head's comrade Corporal Adam Tucker told the court about her final moments, saying she had made safe one bomb before a second one knocked her off her feet.

He said she returned to their vehicle, smoked "a few cigarettes and made light of it".

Cpl Tucker added: "Being the stubborn Yorkshire woman that she was, she said she was quite happy to continue and went back down the alley."

While defusing a second IED, she knelt down and triggered a third five kilogram device that blew off both her legs, right arm and the fingers on her left hand.

Cpl Tucker and colleagues raced down the alley, applied emergency dressings and called in a helicopter.

Capt Head of Huddersfield, West Yorks, was taken to hospital at Camp Bastion, then flown to the Queen Elizabeth military hospital in Birmingham, where she died on April 19.

Recording a verdict of unlawful killing, Bradford Coroner Prof Paul Marks paid tribute to the soldier.

He said: "I cannot praise too highly the courage of Lisa Head."

pages.headline: Facebook time among factors for easy life
pages.teaser: TIME spent using tech among factors boffins find which equate to having easy life
pages.articlebody:
HOW many hours we spend on Facebook, the comfort of our sofas and how close we live to the pub can be used to calculate our easy our lives are, according to boffins.

Brainy Steve Humble, a Fellow at the Institute of Mathematics, has compiled a formula to work out the stress levels of our days.

Other factors revealed in the equation - commissioned by Pot Noodle - included time spent commuting and how often you treat yourself.

Psychologist Honey Langcaster-James worked with Steve on the formula which translates to being the higher your percentage, the easier your life.

She said: "Psychological studies have long shown how certain aspects of your every day life can have a huge effect on your life satisfaction overall, and how stressed your feel".

Honey also identified the number one contributing easy life factor as having close friends to turn to "in times of need".

This is closely followed by how relaxed your boss is. She added: "As we spend most of our day at work or school, the person in charge can have a real affect on how difficult our daily lives are."

pages.subdeck: Road king ... modified Ford GT
pages.headline: Daredevil's 257mph dash in a tuned-up Ford GT
pages.teaser: DAREDEVIL driver set new standing mile world record  but says he can go faster
pages.articlebody:
A DAREDEVIL driver has smashed a world record by hitting an incredible 257mph in a modified Ford.

Sean Kennedy, 29, took to a Texas runway to set a standing mile world record  achieving the fastest ever speed at the end of a mile run-up.

His record-breaking dash, in a highly-tuned Ford GT, saw him hitting a massive 200mph just halfway to the finish line.

The petrolhead had borrowed the supercar from local businessman Mark Heidaker.

But despite his world-beating effort, American Sean says he's confident he can go even quicker.

He said: "I was impressed with how hard it pulled in fourth and fifth gears on that run.

"I think I can do better in the lower gears next time, and we can run an even better speed.

"We want to go 260mph."

The Ford GT Sean was driving was fitted with a 5.4-litre V8 engine and kitted out with two massive turbochargers.

Third grader Austin Worthen dribbled the ball up to the centre of the court before lobbing it the rest of the way and straight into the hoop.

pages.subdeck: Clever canine ... George the Basset Hound dialled 999
pages.headline: Choking dog saves its own life by dialling 999
pages.teaser: SMART pooch paws the emergency number while being strangled by phone cord
pages.articlebody:
COPS who raced to a house after hearing desperate heavy breathing during an emergency call found a DOG had rung 999 while strangling itself with the telephone wire.

George, the two-year-old Basset Hound, had knocked the phone to the floor and got entangled in the wire  winding it round his neck.

And he panicked so much he incredibly managed to ring 999 as he pawed at the phone trying to free himself.

The emergency operator alerted police who dashed to the empty home of driving instructor Steve Brown and his daughter Lydia, 18 on Saturday night.

They were preparing to smash down the door when a family friend from a nearby house ran out with a key to let them in.

Four officers sprinted through the house in South Hiendley, West Yorkshire, searching the rooms.

And then neighbour Paul Walker walked into the living room and found terrified George choking  with the phone lead wound tightly round his neck.

Paul, 41, ripped the phone apart to wrench the wire from George's throat.

He said: "The police split up and ran through the house thinking someone had either been attacked or was desperately ill.

"I went to look round as well and walked into this room and saw George choking.

"He was absolutely terrified and could not free himself.

"I knew I had to get him free quickly so I just ripped the wire out.

"Incredibly you could see where his paw print was on the phone to ring 999  he literally saved his own life.

"When the police came into the room and realised what had happened they burst out laughing.

"They told me they had been sent out because of a 999 call in which the operator could only hear heavy breathing and gasping.

"They thought someone had collapsed or been attacked."

Paul had been left a key by college student Lydia to feed George later in the evening while she went out to do an evening shift as a waitress.

Lydia said: "By the time I got back the police had gone and George was looking a little sorry for himself.

"It is just so lucky that his paw managed to ring 999 otherwise he would have died.

"We still don't know how he managed it.

"It's one of those old-fashioned phones with the dialling ring.

"He's not usually very smart.

"He's really dopey and just likes to chew socks."

Her owner lets out the sulcata tortoise, named Laosi, on sunny days so she can wander around the streets.

Shoppers were clearly delighted, as Laosi quickly attracted a crowd in Nanning, southern China.

She was later rewarded with fresh vegetables she shared with two smaller tortoises.

pages.headline: House for sale...would suit pantomime dwarf
pages.teaser: MINIATURE 1-bedroomed house goes on sale in the UK for just £60,000
pages.articlebody:
IT'S WELL known the housing market has been shrinking for a while, but this is ridiculous.

This tiny home is so small the estate agents marketing it are suggesting you use the landing as a BATHROOM.

The miniature house, which comes with just 325 square foot of space, is on the market for £60,000, and requires some serious renovation.

The Suffolk home comes with an outside loo, and according to the company marketing it  is "deceptively" large.

However, a quick look at the particulars shows it is in desperate need of renovation.

Estate agent Clarke and Simpson, who have the house on the market, say the house is a "charming" property could suit first-time buyers, or anyone looking to really downsize".

He said: "It's quite a charming little home and is actually deceptively larger looking from the outside.

"Quite a lot would need to be spent on it. It has a landing area which could serve as the bathroom.

"It might go to a first-time buyer who is pretty handy with DIY. Or it may be seen as an investment for someone to rent out.

"There are not many properties which sell for that sort of money."

The house, situated in Chapel road in Wickham Market, Suffolk, will be put up for auction on April if it does not get snapped up sooner. The village it is situated in is pretty, has a medieval church and is just a few miles from the seaside.

The tiny sitting room measures 10ft 11in by 8ft 6in and the bedroom is just 9ft 6in by 8ft 3in It also has a small kitchen, landing area, outside WC, store shed and a very small courtyard garden with no room to extend the property.

The property comes close to being one of the smallest houses in the country behind The Check House in nearby Framlingham, Suffolk, which went for £92,000 last year and is just 308 square foot.

pages.subdeck: Chaos ... bus on fire in Tottenham during riots
pages.headline: Riots blamed on poor parenting
pages.teaser: LEAKED report blames lack of parental responsibility and opportunities for young
pages.articlebody:
PARENTS shirking their responsibilities have been blamed for the horrific violence and loss of life witnessed during last year's London riots in a leaked report.

It also claims a lack of opportunities for young people led to widespread unrest and looting last summer.

The report, by the Riots, Communities and Victims Panel, also blamed a lack of confidence in the police, a society that had become too materialistic and a failure to tackle reoffending.

It said: "We heard from many communities who felt that rioter behaviour could ultimately be ascribed to poor parenting."

Five people died in the violence and the clean-up bill was estimated at £200million.

The Government responded by announcing it would try to tackle a hard core of 120,000 troubled families.

But the report said the claim they had been responsible for the unrest was weak.

It suggests schools are fined in the future if pupils cannot read and write properly when they leave.

The riots erupted two days after police shot dead Mark Duggan in Tottenham, North London  the scene of some of the most violent scenes last August.

Looting and arson attacks continued across London and in other cities including Manchester, Bristol, Birmingham and Liverpool for four days.

DANCING On Ice champion Matthew Wolfenden is marking his victory  with a visit to hospital for TWO MRI scans.

The Emmerdale star beat Jorgie Porter and Chico Slimani in Sunday night's final but the gruelling competition has left him suffering a catalogue of injuries.

Between rehearsals with his ice partner Nina Ulanova, Matthew kept up working five days a week playing David Metcalfe in the ITV soap.

He told TV Biz: "I've bust both my tendons in my ankles. I've had my feet in a bucket of ice every day for weeks to take the pain down.

"I can't lift my right arm properly so I'm going for an MRI scan on Tuesday. I think it's to do with my rotator cuff.

"Then when I have the MRI scan on my shoulder, I need to have one on my knee too because when I dropped Nina out of the headbanger in training, I landed on my knee and I've ripped all the bits in the back of it.

"My back and wrist hurts from the lifts and I've done my groin in.

"I've got a week off the ice to let everything relax, then the tour starts. But I've no time off work."

Matthew trained to be a gymnast from the age of four but had to quit the British team after breaking his back in a fall from the rings aged 17. Due to the stress of training, his old spinal injury flared up again.

He said: "It's definitely affected me on Dancing On Ice. I've had back problems since week two when I trapped a nerve."

Partner Nina added: "He'll never admit it but he is in a lot of pain." The injury to his shoulder is so bad that Matthew thinks he would have LOST if the competition had gone on for another week.

On Sunday night's show the judges could see him struggling to get Nina above his head and Matthew said: "Midway through the competition those lifts were popping up dead easily and yesterday it was really hard.

"I don't think I'd have coped with the lifts if we'd had one more week to go. If the final had been next week then I think we'd have had to take all the lifts out."

Nina also got a share of injuries throughout the series. Not only did Matthew repeatedly drop her as he practised his lifts, he also slashed her leg open with the toe picks on his boots, leaving her with a huge scar.

He said: "We put in blood, sweat and tears  lots of blood."

Matthew and Hollyoaks star Jorgie had to pull off three routines in the final  a showcase dance, their favourite routine from the series and their version of Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean's Bolero dance. Show judges and Olympians Katarina Witt and Robin Cousins said Matthew could have been an international ice skating champ if he had started at a young age.

Now he is hoping to get his toddler son Buster  whose mum is Matthew's co-star fiancée Charley Webb  to try ice skating.

Matthew said: "Our northern coach, Stephen Pickavance, told me, 'You should have done this as a kid, you'd have gone so far.'

"I'm definitely going to get Buster on the ice now this has all finished because it's brilliant and he'll love it.

"Now I can whizz him around and I feel confident enough. It will be great."

Matthew thought he would never win a sporting trophy again after his gymnastic career was over, but winning Dancing On Ice is a great consolation prize.

He said: "It was amazing to win in an Olympic year. This makes up for the gymnastics a little bit. Training was my life until I had my accident and broke my back."

Matthew has been a huge hit with fans on Dancing On Ice but he insists he will never quit his soap role.

He said: "I don't want to leave Emmerdale. It's my bread and butter and they've been so accommodating throughout this whole show.

"Everyone at Emmerdale is just brilliant. I've signed a contract that takes me to Christmas then, hopefully, I'll get a new one after that too."

Matthew revealed he has a huge storyline coming up  and hinted that David's ex-girlfriend Leyla Harding (Rokhsaneh Ghawam-Shahidi) could be returning to cause trouble for him.

He said: "I've got a big new storyline. It's to do with Alicia and David and the little one, Jacob.

pages.subdeck: On road to recovery ... Robin Gibb composed The Titanic Requiem while undergoing chemo
pages.headline: Robin Gibb: Writing Titanic music helped me to battle cancer
pages.teaser: HOW working on symphony marking 100 years since Titanic disaster helped Bee Gee
pages.articlebody:
IT is a maritime disaster that has always fascinated.

April 15 marks 100 years since the "unsinkable" liner RMS Titanic hit an iceberg on its maiden voyage and sank, claiming 1,517 lives.

In a series ahead of the anniversary, this week we explore stories of the Titanic.

Here pop legend Robin Gibb reveals the extraordinary personal circumstances which led to his interest in the tragedy and how it shaped his music.

HE has had a hand in writing some of pop music's most memorable hits, and has sold more than 200million records worldwide.

But it was writing a symphony about the sinking of the Titanic which helped pull Robin Gibb through a personal tragedy.

The Bee Gee has had a lifelong fascination with the ship, and to mark the 100th anniversary of the disaster he has composed his first classical work The Titanic Requiem, with son RJ, 29.

Robin says concentrating his energies on the piece helped him battle liver cancer.

He was diagnosed with the disease last year and is now recovering.

In an exclusive interview with The Sun, Robin, 62, said: "I'm truly grateful that working on The Titanic Requiem distracted me from my illness to such a degree that I truly believe it might have saved my life."

Robin's fascination with the Titanic story stems from boyhood, when he was caught up in a violent storm at sea.

He said: "One of my earliest memories goes back to when I was a little boy of seven and my grandmother told me how her mother cried floods of tears when she heard that the Titanic had sunk.

"Then, when I was eight and me and my family were sailing to Australia to start our musical career and begin a new life, we got caught in a monsoon.

"At times the waves flung the boat high, the next minute deep in a trough. The passengers were collapsing all over the deck and being sick but I wasn't.

"Then the captain made the announcement, 'Do not worry. There hasn't been a tragedy at sea since the Titanic went down in 1912'.

"It wasn't true, of course, or heartening for us passengers. But yet again, the spectre of the Titanic had been raised."

Robin, his brothers and their parents were almost killed at sea themselves when, in 1967 on the way back from Australia, their ship travelled through the Suez Canal.

He recalls: "A civil war was going on in Aden and our boat was fired upon. We were all ordered off the deck and into our cabins. It was quite exciting at the time but we could have all been killed."

That same year Robin narrowly missed losing his life again, when he and his then wife-to-be, Molly, were involved in the Hither Green rail disaster, in south London, in which 49 people died. He says: "I felt on top of the world that morning as the Bee Gees had just had a big hit with Massachusetts. Looking back, Massachusetts probably saved my life.

"Until that record hit the Top Ten I would never have been able to afford a First Class train ticket. But on that occasion, because Massachusetts was doing so well, I did.

"And like everyone else travelling First Class that day, both Molly and I had more chance of surviving the crash than those who weren't.

"But though we did survive, I saw harrowing things I've never forgotten.

"Headless bodies being dragged out of the train wreck, people screaming.

"Molly and I were rushed to hospital in Lewisham so we could be examined for injuries. I had broken glass from the train windows tangled in my hair.

"It took days to remove it but that was really the least of it. The shock and the horror was far, far worse. When we got to the hospital it looked like a war zone. All around us people were being carried in on stretchers and some of their injuries were horrific. Suddenly, it all became too much for me.

"The worst thing of all was that I was unable to help anyone, to mitigate their suffering, I couldn't cope with that.

"I knew I had to get away from all the carnage so I checked out of the hospital and instead went to stay with the Bee Gees' manager, Robert Stigwood.

"After that I suffered a delayed reaction. For days and days I couldn't stop crying. In the end the only thing which saved me was my music, composing with my brothers and singing again.

"But although I did recover, I'll never really forget the horror of the Hither Green train crash and the tragedy of all those poor souls who died or were injured in it."

Robin makes it clear that he does not think living through the rail disaster qualifies him for understanding the Titanic tragedy more than others. However, he believes it is easier for him to walk in the shoes of the doomed Titanic passengers.

As an avid collector of Titanic memorabilia, he has always been obsessed by the tragedy.

His collection includes a pen fashioned from pieces of the wreckage.

It was a present from second wife Dwina, who also gave one to RJ.

And that led him to change tack from composing pop music and, with RJ  also a talented musician  embark on composing his first classical work.

Robin adds: "It has taken us two years to complete The Titanic Requiem.

"Two years of dedication, and I'm definitely very proud of it."

RJ is also proud of the composition, and equally proud of his father's courage in working day and night on it while undergoing chemotherapy to combat his cancer.

RJ says: "He kept going on against all odds. He has been every inch a professional and he deserves a medal for it. For him to come straight out of chemotherapy and into the studio is incredible.

"We've always been close but working on a piece of music that is meant to last for hundreds of years brought us even closer.

"We composed the requiem in order to honour the memory of those who died and to celebrate the age in which they lived."

Robin adds: "I never pushed RJ to become a musician, though. I wanted him to excel at whatever he wanted to do but I never pressured him.

"As he grew older it turned out that he had a flare for melody, and like me and my brothers, who never had music lessons, he flourished. Our collaboration has been wonderful. We have already started working on our next joint classical composition, The First World War Requiem.

"But neither of us will be giving up pop music, either. RJ will be recording an album, Instant Love, and I will be working with Barry again, I'm looking forward to it.

"I just hope that The Titanic Requiem will be a fitting memorial for all those brave souls who died during the tragedy, so they will never be forgotten."

One of the most moving elements in the requiem is the song Don't Cry Alone, which Robin sings. It tells of a man who knows he is going to die begging his wife not to cry alone when he's gone.

It is a song that Dwina finds particularly emotional.

GEORGE Sampson is planning his first tattoo  as soon as he's bulked up.

The Streetdance 2 star wants an old-fashioned streetlamp, as a tribute to the Singing In The Rain routine which won him the 2008 series of Britain's Got Talent.

He said: "I'm waiting for me to put on a bit of weight. My metabolism at the moment is very high and when it slows down and I get a bit bigger, and I gain a bit of muscle, then I will get a tattoo.

"I think I want an old English lamppost up my back, but instead of a pole I want writing scribbled, but I don't know what it will be yet. As soon as I've figured it out I will get one.

"It comes from Singing in The Rain  and my friend told me this really good quote: 'It's not about waiting for the storm to pass, it's about learning to dance in the rain.'"

Although he turned 18 while filming the Streetdance sequel, he tells The Sun he still has to get his mum's approval over the design.

He said: "My mum has been very fussy about this thing because I've been talking for ages about getting one but she says, 'Until you know what you want and you're happy with it, really happy with it, you're not getting one.'"

In Streetdance 2, George goes from the background to the spotlight as returning character Eddie.

Together with fellow streetdancer Ash (Falk Hentshel) he gathers the best dancers from around the world in an attempt to beat top streetdance crew Invincible.

Their plans take a new twist when they discover hot Latin dancer Eva, played by Sofia Boutella, and try for a new dance fusion.

Manchester lad George, who also stars in Waterloo Road, turned 18 on the shoot in Berlin.

But the celebrations weren't as epic as he'd hoped.

He explained: "At the start of it they told me that they weren't shooting the day after my birthday, so I thought, 'Ok, so that's a really good opportunity to get drunk on my 18th birthday.'

"Then we were shooting the day after my birthday and I was in the first scene in the morning so we didn't really drink too much.

"I had kept it kind of quiet but the whole cast, the producers, the choreographers and the crew all came out, we had a nice big meal and a couple of nice drinks afterwards. It was overwhelming."

The movie reunited George with fellow BGT contestants Flawless and Got To Dance winner Akai.

And Tom Conti joins the cast as Eva's protective uncle Manu.

pages.subdeck: 'My photo journey reminds me how hard I worked' ... Nicola Williams
pages.headline: 11st weightloss picture diary
pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined a gym and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."

pages.headline: BURCHILL on Madge's right to be risque
pages.teaser: AFTER flashing some flesh in Miami, there are calls for her to hang up risque costumes
pages.articlebody:
MADONNA has never been what you would call a modest dresser.

But at a Miami gig at the weekend these cheeky hotpants set tongues wagging.

At 53, is it time to hang up the risque costumes?

Here is the view of one controversial writer.

OVER the past three decades I have made more bitchy comments about Madonna than Elton John has.

I still maintain that if ordinary citizens went about showing their sex organs to all and sundry, they'd be locked up, not handsomely rewarded.

But, albeit belatedly, I feel I must come to Madge's defence. Of course popular music is, ideally, a young person's racket.

If all pop stars of both sexes retired from the stage when they were young and fresh, fine.

Take TV. Where's the logic in letting men go on until they look like resentful Galapagos tortoises while women are shoved off screen as soon as they can hold a pencil under their breasts?

Women are more than half the population and their eye candy requirements should be catered to.

No one says that George Michael, Madonna's contemporary, should throw in the men-only sauna towel.

Another of her generation, Michael Jackson, was indulged when it came to the ageing process, still playing the Peter Pan card when he frankly looked more like Baby Jane.

Mick Jagger is a decade and a half older than Madonna, yet is still the shrivelled subject of such ludicrous tributes as Moves Like Jagger.

The writer Truman Capote called him "about as sexy as a p***ing toad"  and now he looks as if a bored giant practised origami on his face for a very long time before throwing the mangled plaything aside.

When Clive Dunn crooned Grandad on Top Of The Pops in the Seventies, he spent hours in make-up to look the part.

But Jagger, McCartney, Tom Jones  the prancing grandads are for real now. So why the vapours over Madonna in her shorts when she still has the body of a woman half her age?

If women are past it at 50, think about men and the way their bodies specifically become unappetising. Most of them are more Wayne Rooney than George Clooney to start with and time is rarely kind.

What's sauce for the goose is good for the gander  and next to a pair of knee-length, wizened testicles (yes, I KNOW we can't see them, but we all KNOW they're there) what's a bit of turkey neck?

Go, Madge! Just keep your pants on this time...
