pages.subdeck: Regrets ... Michelle Pfeiffer reveals what she wishes she'd known at 18
pages.headline: What I wish I'd known at 18
pages.teaser: THE Hollywood star now recognises the importance of a good education
pages.articlebody:
MICHELLE PFEIFFER became famous thanks to 1980s films such as The Witches Of Eastwick, Dangerous Liaisons and The Fabulous Baker Boys.

She had established herself as one of the world's best-known actresses by the time she cut back on movies to bring up her family.

She has adopted daughter Claudia Rose, 18, and son John Henry, 17, with second husband, TV producer David E. Kelley.

Michelle, 53, who co-stars with Johnny Depp in upcoming film Dark Shadows, is also known for her work with charities helping cancer patients. Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE what she wished she knew aged 18.

"I WISH I had known at 18 the importance of education.

I was always at the beach. I couldn't wait to get out of school. I was so bored.

I was a California girl to a T, being brought up in Midway City between Los Angeles and San Diego.

I was not a good girl and always in trouble for something or other.

Looking back, I wish I had paid more attention  and I also regret that I did not have teachers who were more interested in me.

When I became a mother, I realised I had not taken enough advantage of my education and came to appreciate how important it really is.

That is completely different to having success.

There are people who have had no education who have made a lot of their lives.

If you are not careful, education can just slip by and it is sometimes hard to get a second chance.

I'd also taken up acting at school because I was so bad at English and thought I would improve by taking theatre studies. But becoming an actress was as unobtainable as going to the moon  or becoming president.

I had worked, part-time, as a check-out girl in a supermarket since the age of 14 and, in the end, I left school at 17 and worked there full-time. I had not learned a thing.

I was living with my parents at home, working the check-out, spending time on the beach and realised I'd better do something with my life. I called a friend of mine, Walter Deadman, who was a hairdresser, who had always been harping on at me to model.

I told him I would like to become an actress.

Instead of laughing, he suggested I join a beauty pageant. I called up a modelling agent, John Robert Powers, who ran a sort of charm school.

I borrowed a dress  I never wore them because they used to call me chicken legs at high school  and went along for some test shots. I used those to put myself up for the pageant.

So I went to LA for the first time in my life for the pageant. The biggest stress was that I smoked and I'd have to give it up for a week! I won a prize, because they suddenly decided they wanted a Miss Orange County. In truth, they had more crowns than people.

But winning that pageant did change my life. I moved out of my parents' house to about half a mile down the road and about six months later signed with an agent.

I got a TV series and did not have to work at the supermarket any more. After that, what happened to me felt very dreamlike  a Disneyland experience, which changed me.

But I also wish I'd have known how being recognised would bother me far more than it should.

I found it disturbing and completely unnatural. There is nothing to prepare you.

I wish I could have handled it better, initially.

I have learned since that it is possible to have both a home life and a working life. The worst moment was when there was a radio report, in the late 1990s, that David had left me for Ally McBeal actress Calista Flockhart  and we were both listening in the car, with the kids!

They gave an on-air apology the next day and I have never heard a more grovelling retraction. But it is hard dealing with that kind of stuff.

I also struggled with my own image as a sexual person.

That ended with a film, The Fabulous Baker Boys in 1989, by which time I was 31.

Even two years before that, I would not have been able to play the part of the sexually appealing Susie Diamond. She was dynamic and unapologetic and I was able to put on those clothes and play the part. I think, because of the way I looked, I had stayed away from buying anything sexy or overtly sexual.

It was a turning point for me, because I could understand why men would find her sexy.

I wish I'd been more like her. Before that, I would walk around looking like a bag lady!

But the biggest turning point in my life was becoming a mother. If you had told me when I was 18 that I could survive on three hours' sleep a night, I'd have never believed it. You just cope.

I would not choose a showbusiness career for my children.

I would say: 'Be a doctor, or something else'. The value of a good education has never left me."

pages.subdeck: Golden girl ... Jennifer Lawrence is set for superstardom following her latest role
pages.headline: I was too 'fat' to be heroine
pages.teaser: JENNIFER Lawrence had to dye her hair brown and train 3 times a day to prepare for film
pages.articlebody:
IT'S the movie everyone's talking about  and could even put vampire hit Twilight in the shade.

The Hunger Games, which has just opened in the UK, took a whopping $155million (£98million) at the US box office on its opening weekend.

That was the third biggest total ever after Harry Potter And The Deathly Hallows Part 2 and The Dark Knight.

The success of The Hunger Games  a futuristic action movie based on a best-selling trilogy of novels  is set to make star Jennifer Lawrence as big a name as Twilight's Kristen Stewart.

And that is despite fans of the books saying she was "too fat, too pretty and too blonde" to play heroine Katniss Everdeen.

Jennifer, 21, said: "I didn't know until the interviewers told me that all the fans were p****d because I was blonde.

"Then I was like, 'What? Damn, I'll just dye my hair'."

The actress had to endure months of gruelling training to get in shape for the role.

She said: "It was intense. I had training about three times a day for a few months. Then, once we started working, I had to have the training just for endurance because it was so many hours.

"I mean, if there's a scene of me running up a mountain, that's what we shot all day  me running up a mountain.

"I had about six weeks of archery. It was brand new to me and I loved it. I think I'm good at shooting arrows now  and I can skin a squirrel!"

The action was so intense that the star, who is dating British actor Nicholas Hoult, 22, had a constant battle to keep weight on.

She said: "It was great to lose weight because it was unintentional. I didn't go to the gym once. It was just a really physical movie.

"I actually ate more on that movie than I ever have on any other because it was non-stop and physical and I needed energy.

"It happened very naturally with all the training. It was hard to keep weight on for continuity.

"I ate a ton. Any picture you see of me from that set, I'm probably eating."

Jennifer jumped at the chance to play the lead role.

She said: "I loved the books. That was the hardest part for me.

"I almost wished I didn't love them as much as I did because of just the pressure I put on myself to make sure it was something I could be happy about and proud of.

"Katniss is such an iconic character and there is so much pressure just coming from myself because I was a fan."

The movie, based on Suzanne Collins' novels, is set in a future North America destroyed by drought, fire, famine and war.

Each year inhabitants are forced to take part in a televised fight to the death.

Jennifer said: "I think it makes us look at humanity in kind of a real way, where it is is becoming desensitised.

"We can watch the demise of a marriage or we can watch death on television and it's entertainment.

"We're a society that's obsessed with reality. We're obsessed with gossip and bad things happening rather than good stories and good, uplifting things. We live in a world where history repeats itself and it's (the events of the movie) really not that far off, I don't think."

Jennifer is quickly rising up the ranks in Hollywood thanks to the new movie on top of past success. She was nominated for an Oscar last year for her role in thriller Winter's Bone  but she says she does not feel like a star.

She said: "The glamorous part lasts for about five minutes and it doesn't even really feel glamorous. So it just feels like a job. Being on a set is not glamorous.

"I don't really think about it because I don't really like going out that much.

"I'm kind of a home body, so I was stressing out one time about movies and that I won't be able to go out to dinner  I won't be able to go to a bar and just hang out.

"But then I'm always lying to get out of those things anyway. So now I just have an excuse  'I can't go, I'm famous'.

"I guess I feel I have to be more mature. I can't really, like, moon the paparazzi or anything, which is always my dream."

Jennifer, who auditioned for the part of Bella in Twilight, was also in X-Men: First Class last year. But she doesn't want to fall into Hollywood's traps.

She explained: "It is so strange to see in Hollywood how skinny these women are and how that puts pressure on our young girls.

"I remember being in school when I was 14 and girls were on diets and eating salads with dressing on the side. It was just weird.

"It's not healthy because I don't really think that's beautiful. Every time somebody talks about skinny, nobody ever writes how great it is to be skinny and how everyone loves someone who is skinny.

"They're always writing about when this fad is going to end. I can't wait for it to end."

Jennifer plays a former sex addict in forthcoming movie The Silver Linings Playbook, which also stars legend Robert De Niro.

She said: "Fantastic  Robert De Niro. I can't believe I can even talk to him really but he's just so down-to-earth and nice and normal."

And although she is now dating Nicholas she admits there is another British actor she has the hots for  Clive Owen.

After The Hunger Games, most red-blooded men will have the hots for Jennifer too.

Hunger Games facts



THE Hunger Games trilogy of novels has been translated into 26 languages and is on sale in 38 countries.

A whopping ten million copies of the books were sold last year alone.

Writer Suzanne Collins, 50, whose first Hunger Games book came out in 2008, is now Amazon Kindle's best-selling author. She was the first author writing material for young adults to sell more than one million Kindle ebooks.

Catching Fire  the second in the trilogy  was published in 2009 and Mockingjay came out in 2010.

Suzanne said she got the inspiration for the books after surfing channels on her TV. One programme on at the time was a reality TV show and the other was footage of the Iraq War. She said: "The two began to blur in a very unsettling way."

Now the books and the film are so successful that a doll of lead character Katniss is being released.

Thousands of fans have been travelling to North Carolina, where the movie was shot, to do Hunger Games tours. One place featured in the film is Henry River Mill Village. pages.teaser: STUDENT Rearna has spent months planning her big day even though she's SINGLE
pages.articlebody:
STUDENT Rearna Ackord has been organising her wedding for six months.

The 22-year-old has selected the venue and picked out her £1,100 dream dress.

She has also chosen the song that will play as she walks down the aisle and finalised a menu her guests will be served.

But there is one thing missing from her big day  the groom.

She is one of a growing group of women called the Single Bridezillas, who have planned their weddings down to the last tea light, despite the fact they don't even have a boyfriend.

Rearna, who is reading English Literature at university, said: "Every girl grows up dreaming of their wedding day, fantasising about how they will look and whether their mum will cry.

"I'm just taking it one step further than most and making those dreams a reality."

Rearna was bitten by the bridal bug last year when she visited St Bartholomew's Church near where she studies in Brighton.

She said: "After a string of failed relationships, I used to be the type of girl who couldn't think of anything worse than getting married.

"But when, last year, I went inside that church I had a life-changing moment."

Taking in the beautiful architecture, long aisle and stunning stain glass windows Rearna was "blown away" by the place.

She said: "It was stunning. All of a sudden I could see myself in a gorgeous white dress, walking down the aisle with all my friends and family looking on proudly.

"In that moment I decided I had to get married and started planning straight away. I wanted to put my name on the wedding waiting list there and then."

Within minutes of returning home, Rearna decided both her dad Des, 54, and brother Landon, 19, would walk her down the aisle to the song A Case Of You by James Blake.

She said: "It's such a beautiful song, when I heard it on the radio I instantly said 'That's it'."

Ever since her visit to the church ten months ago, Rearna is "like a woman possessed."

Despite her friends mocking her sudden obsession with her fantasy wedding, Rearna hasn't stopped giving them details of her big day.

She admitted: "My friends laugh at me. They couldn't understand when I first told them I'd started to plan a wedding without a boyfriend.

"Suddenly, bridal shops and wedding magazines became interesting.

"Looking through them for ideas, my mind raced with thoughts of invites, flowers and, of course, the dress."

Rearna was in Uckfield, East Sussex, for a day when she saw an ivory dress on a mannequin in the window of Fross Wedding Collections.

She said: "I stopped in my tracks. I'd seen dresses I liked in the magazines but nothing compared to this.

"I knew straight away it was the dress I was going to get married in and booked an appointment for later that day to try it on.

"My friend Leah Butson  she's a student too  and I both had tears in our eyes as I twirled in front of the mirror with the circular train trailing behind me. It was the stuff of dreams."

Returning home that night, unable to stop thinking about her dream dress, Rearna began to panic that the dress would sell out before she had the funds to buy it.

She said: "I just know how upset I'll be if I finally saved up the money only to find out it's gone. The only way is to put down a deposit of £150, so I'm going to have to save so I can be safe in the knowledge it's mine.

"I go in to try it on at least once a month and because I've been doing it for the past seven months shop owner knows me by name.

"I've even considered taking out a loan to cover the £1,100 to put my mind at rest."

Rearna now visits the church every month to visualise her big day and measure up to work out how many flowers she will need.

She explained: "I sit and picture how it will look. I've planned to have the whole interior lit up with a thousand tea light candles and the pews to be draped with off-white silk. I love animals, so I've asked my best friend if her dogs can be involved. They're going to be dressed in little suits and dresses and will accompany the bridesmaids down the aisle.

"My friend Kirsty Naunton makes amazing cakes so I instantly got her on the phone to discuss what I wanted.

"The chosen cake is three tiers with white icing and diamante-style decorations."

To make sure her dream wedding will not become a distant fantasy, Rearna has made a pact with a close friend, 23-year-old Jonny Gregson, that if neither is married by the age of 30, they'll tie the knot.

She said: "Age 28 is my goal so I have a few years to find someone, finalise my plans and save the £30,000 I need."

Although she's missing a groom, Rearna couldn't wait to break the news to those who make up the rest of the bridal party.

Best friends Olivia Jones, 21, Leah, 22, Kirsty Naunton, 22, and Lil Griffin, 21, will all be bridesmaids.

She said: "Although they think I'm mad, they're all excited.

"I have already taken them to the shop to show them the pink dresses they'll be wearing."

With the ceremony planned in fine detail, Rearna will be taking her guests to the nearby beach for the reception in a giant marquee.

She said: "Living in Brighton, I've decided to have a party on the beach.

"Watching the sun set with my family and friends and new husband will be so amazing."

The single bride-to-be does not want to leave any part unplanned so Rearna has recently finalised her food menu.

She said: "My grandma Daisy Ackord is Jamaican and she makes the best food I've ever tasted, so she's in charge of catering for my big day. I'm going to have a West Indian menu consisting of jerk chicken, specialty rice and peas, ackee and saltfish and special Jamaican cakes for dessert."

Rearna and her gran have worked out the Caribbean feast will cost £50 a head. And for the music, she will hire a jazz-funk band.

She said: "I come from a very musical family and we're all big jazz fans so I've been keeping an eye out for one that can cater for weddings."

Every time someone mentions getting married, Rearna always tries to slip in a mention of St Bartholomew's.

The singleton even spoke to someone who had been married at the venue. When they revealed they had trouble with parking she immediately factored in plans to have minibuses bring guests to the venue.

Despite living on her student loan, Rearna is already trying to save the £30,000 she's worked out she needs for her big day.

She said: "The first thing I'm going to spend my first proper pay cheque on is my wedding dress.

"I'm completely obsessed with it and can't wait to have it hung in my wardrobe instead of in a shop window."

But Rearna is under no illusions  she knows the detail with which she has planned her big day could send a new boyfriend running a mile.

She said: "When I do meet someone I'll be keeping these plans firmly under wraps  until I have a ring on my finger..."

pages.headline: Toxic breast implants killed my baby
pages.teaser: A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby
pages.articlebody:
A GRIEVING mum has blamed toxic PIP breast implants for killing her unborn baby.

Suzanne Ellis believes son Ivan was stillborn after being poisoned by the ruptured implants.

She claimed they leaked industrial-strength silicone  which is used for stuffing mattresses  into her body.

Suzanne said doctors could find no other explanation for the death and is pressing for a probe into the tragedy.

She is also backing The Sun's Safer Surgery campaign for tighter regulations and a Government-backed national register of procedures.

Suzanne, 31, of Widnes, Cheshire, said: "When I decided to have implants, I thought I knew all the risks. I never thought losing my son would be one of them."

She had her breasts enlarged in Manchester in 2007. But after six months one started to swell and she had chest, ear and throat infections.

Suzanne, who has a 14-year-old daughter, then suffered chronic headaches before falling pregnant  when her symptoms got worse. She said: "I'd been pregnant before, but this was horrific."

She developed an intense itching across her body. Suzanne said: "I felt like there was something under my skin. It was awful." Doctors were baffled, but her unborn baby appeared to be OK and Suzanne called him Ivan. But at 27 weeks he was stillborn.

Suzanne said: "I needed answers but nobody could tell me why my perfect baby had died." She and her ex-partner Adam declined a post mortem at the time.

Tests showed a healthy placenta and the cause of death remained a mystery to consultants.

A year after her loss, Suzanne noticed a lump on her breast.

Doctors said her right implant had ruptured  and that it had been made by PIP.

The French company is at the centre of an international health scare over the faulty implants which were given to up to 40,000 British women.

Suzanne, who is waiting to have her implants removed, said: "No wonder I'd been so ill. No wonder my baby died. The manufacturers of PIP implants put my health at risk and risked the life of my son. How many other women have suffered?"

  • SUN doctor CAROL COOPER writes: Nobody knows if PIP implants killed Ivan. There have been no studies into whether they harm babies.

    Any implant is a "foreign body" and could provoke a reaction. Research is still being done. Pregnant women should get advice from their GP.

pages.subdeck: Honeytrapper ... Mundill Mahil smirks as she arrives at the Old Bailey
pages.headline: Honeytrapper could be free in 3yrs
pages.teaser: DISTRAUGHT sister's fury at six-year sentence for 20-year-old honeytrapper Mundill Mahil
pages.articlebody:
STANDING in front of the shrine to her murdered brother, Amandip is distraught and angry  and feels betrayed.

TV boss Gagandip Singh was just 21 when he was lured to his death in a honeytrap  viciously beaten and burned alive in the boot of a Mercedes car.

Amandip, 19, a business studies student, said: "My mother and I are haunted by the way Gagandip was murdered. We saw his horrifically burned body and we cannot get that image out of our minds."

Medical student Mundill Mahil, 20, was jailed last month for six years for GBH with intent. Harvinder Shoker, also 20, got life for murder, while 20-year-old Darren Peters was jailed for 12 years for manslaughter.

Now, Amandip and her mum Tajinder have asked the Attorney General to review the sentence handed to Mahil and set up an e-petition, Justice For Gagandip.

Speaking out for the first time, Amandip added: "He would not have been murdered if Mundill Mahil hadn't lured him to her flat in Brighton in a carefully orchestrated honeytrap.

"Mahil will be released for good behaviour in three years. It's outrageous. Other cases involving money and fraud get much more punishment. Gagandip's life has been taken. I believe something more needs to be done."

Gagandip's body was found in the burning car in Blackheath, south-east London, in February last year.

He had been violently attacked in Brighton before being driven back to the capital and murdered.

A post-mortem examination revealed he was still alive when the fire in the car was started.

It was the second tragedy for the family in just 18 months. In September 2009 Gagandip's father Charanjit was murdered in India. Eight people are on trial there accused of being involved.

Gagandip took over his dad's packaging firm and also started the Sikh TV channel on Sky.

Amandip said: "We were only just starting to come to terms with the first murder when Gagan was killed. It has knocked the life out of me and Mum."

The court heard that Mahil, from Chatham, Kent, had been Gagandip's girlfriend. He was in love but they split up in August 2010 after she alleged he had sexually assaulted her.

Shoker, his friend of five years, also fell in love with Mahil and decided to take revenge on the businessman.

In February last year she lured Gagandip to her house in Brighton.

She knew that Shoker and Peters, both from London, would be lying in wait for him.

He was beaten unconscious and bundled into the boot of the car.

Amandip said: "I only met Mahil once, when Gagandip brought her to our home. She was very pretty and confident and seemed a nice person.

"My brother and I were very close and were both living at home and saw each other every day.

"He became very close to her and said she was a friend he trusted and who he could talk to about anything.

"Look at how she betrayed his trust. She tried to destroy my brother's character in court.

"But he was a kind, generous man who would have done anything to help anyone."

Detective Superintendent Damian Allain, who investigated the case, said after the conviction: "Throughout the investigation and trial Mahil portrayed herself as a victim.

"It is clear to me, now endorsed by the jury's verdict, that her actions were calculating and that she was at the heart of a criminal conspiracy with Shoker and Peters of tricking Gagandip to Brighton to seriously assault him, which resulted in his death."

The family say Gagandip had the world at his feet.

Amandip said: "He ran the family's successful employment agency and packaging business. He also set up and headed Sikh TV.

"In addition, he was the founder of the British Sikh Student Federation. He had made friends and contacts all around the world."

His mother Tajinder, 45, was equally proud of his achievements.

She said: "He had done so much. I didn't think a 21-year-old would be capable of so much.

"I'm amazed how much he achieved. Never a day goes by when we don't think about him.

"I am devastated by my son's killing and struggling to cope. In my life there's only a dead end.

"There's nothing left ahead. The whole story has finished here."

She now runs the family business, which employs 300 people. But with the emotional turmoil of losing her son she found it almost impossible to carry on with it.

She said: "When I first learned of Gagandip's death I was completely and utterly broken.

"I could barely function on a day-to-day basis and stumbled through each day not really knowing what was going on. I do not have the support of a husband because he also died not so long before Gagan.

"I cannot describe on an average day my life since Gagandip's death because they have all blended into one.

"In the early stages I couldn't hold a conversation without breaking down in tears and there were occasions when the police had to call an ambulance for me after I collapsed."

Cherished pictures from the family photo album show what a loving son and brother Gagandip was.

There was also a picture of him at his 21st birthday party with killer Shoker.

Amandip said: "Shoker turned up uninvited to the party.

"We knew things weren't right between Gagandip and Shoker by that stage. The photo of them together is so ironic as they look like the best of friends  and for over five years they were.

"I'm sickened by the thought that the man who holds his hand lovingly over my brother's heart in the photo is the same person who later beat him so terribly then burned him alive.

"He spent so much time around at our house that he practically lived here.

"What he did is such a terrible betrayal of trust."

Gagandip was cremated and his ashes scattered in a river at the Kiratpur Sahib temple in the Punjab, India.

Like her mother, Amandip broke down when she remembered the precious times they had together.

She said: "I found it hard to go into his bedroom without getting very upset."

Now, though, they remember him with the shrine in the garden and in his former bedroom in south east London.

Amandip said: "Mum and I actually slept in his room as a way of trying to feel closer to him.

"Now we have turned his bedroom into a shrine, with a large photo of him on the bed and all his clothes and possessions are still in the room."

Gagandip's mum and sister are still clearly in pain over his loss  but their grief would be easier to bear if they felt justice had been done.

Additional reporting: MARK CHRISTY

pages.headline: War widow predicted death
pages.teaser: WIDOW reveals spooky premonitions in book about her husband Sgt Olaf Schmid
pages.articlebody:
WAR widow Christina Schmid read her hero husband's Tarot cards before his fateful tour  with nightmare results.

The burning Tower card, seen as the harbinger of doom, repeatedly cropped up.

It was one of a host of spooky premonitions she had both before and during hubby Oz's fatal five-month mission to the Afghanistan front line, where he defused 70 Taliban bombs.

Today Christina tells of the dreadful day he begged her to read his future  and the moment she saw his destruction in the cards.

In her own words, taken from her memoir about Staff Sergeant Olaf "Oz" Schmid, Always By My Side, she writes: "Oz asked me to do his Tarot cards.

"The Tarot was something I did very rarely, perhaps once every other year. I wasn't sure about doing it this time, but Oz urged me to and I agreed.

"I had done them since I was young and I seemed to be gifted. The card he chose to show the future was the Burning Tower. I did them again, this time for career, Oz chose the Burning Tower again. The worst card there is.

"It signifies death and endings, the worst outcome imaginable and entirely unavoidable. Everything you know gone in ruin or catastrophe.

Oz looked stricken. He said, 'I feel this is going to be a really bad year for me. I've got this feeling as if everything is slipping'.

"I tried to lighten it, saying, 'You'll probably just stub your toe when you're at work  you're always a screamer with loads of bad luck! Don't worry, it might just mean that you won't get a promotion or something'.

"'No', he said. 'It's not the card. That just confirmed what I already know and feel'.

"When it was my turn to choose a card I hoped I might get something that would lift the mood, but I was startled when I got it in my spread of cards, too.

"But then I got rebirth after, and the moon. 'See, hun  always light in the dark. Remember that', he said. I tried to hide my dismay. 'It's a dark time of year. Perhaps we're both just feeling it', I said.

" 'Let's be positive, forget the cards, we've got lots to look forward to', I chirped, waiting for him to follow my lead.

"He usually did, but this time Oz said, 'No, it's bad. I've got this feeling that if I go out after January or February, I'm not coming back. That's what my gut is telling me'. There was nothing I could say that would cheer him and the truth was it was hard even to try, because I felt worried too."

Despite the omen, devoted Christina put aside her foreboding when Oz was sent to the front.

During his dangerous deployment she would make a wish for his protection during the full moon.

But on the last full moon before Oz's return she inexplicably fell asleep with young son Laird and missed her routine.

She writes: "I woke around 4am, disorientated. I was fully clothed and Laird was asleep on me, in his pyjamas. As the realisation dawned that I had missed doing the wish for Oz, the moon had disappeared and I felt distraught.

" 'Oh my God, what have I done?' I whispered. 'I've done it every month. Why now?'

"I told myself it didn't matter, that it was just a bit of silly tradition, that I should forget it. But I couldn't."

Christina's foreboding grew to fever pitch shortly before Oz, who won a gallantry gong on his tour, was due home.

The spooky signs grew to the point where she says she KNEW he was dead even before the fateful news came with a knock on the door from two officers bringing confirmation.

She writes: "Two days before he was due to leave Afghanistan for home, Oz called again. I could hear immediately that he was low.

"He had been out of contact for several days and he sounded shattered. He said, 'Honey, I just feel really bad, I've got this odd feeling, like dread, I don't feel safe, it's bad. Have you got it too?' I had. In the pit of my stomach I felt a lurch as he spoke.

"I had been uneasy, anxious, and had a feeling of dread, but I didn't want to say that.

'You're tired,' I said. 'It's OK, you'll be back soon. Do what you did the last few months in the next couple of days, hun. You've got 48 hours left, that's all'.

" 'Honey', he said, 'I'm mentally and spiritually hammered, I'm hanging out. I've been away too long, worked too much.

" 'And if it's too much for me it's too much for anyone. But I can't let it show. I've got to keep positive and strong, they (the other men) have to trust me. If anything happens to me, I don't want them to blame themselves.

" 'I wish you could come and get me. I need you. Just come and get me now, honey'.

" 'I wish I could', I said, tears running down my face. 'But I can't. You've got to stop talking like this, you're just tired. You can push for 48 hours'. 'I need to speak to Laird,' he said. I handed Laird the phone and he went upstairs and they talked.

"When Laird gave the phone back, Oz said, 'I'm calm, honey, but I can't help how I feel. I don't think I'm coming back, 'cos I'm cuffing it now. I'm drained  it's hard to explain'.

"The next day I kept the phone beside me all evening, hoping he'd ring. I wanted to ring him but I couldn't, so that night I emailed  'Please email me, Don't go out on the ground tomorrow, cut the last day, don't do it.' He never got it."

That night Christina had a visitation in her dreams from another hero bomb hunter, Warrant Officer Gary "Gaz" O'Donnell, who had perished in the Afghan badlands disarming a Taliban device.

She writes: "I slept fitfully then I dreamed that Gaz O'Donnell was standing in front of me. 'Don't worry, Chris, I'm here to get him when he comes over,' he said. 'I'll hold him. I won't let go'.

" 'What are you on about?' I said. 'You've got no arms'. Gaz just looked at me and smiled.

"The next morning, Saturday October 31, 2009, I woke at 6.30am with a feeling I'd never had before. It was as powerful as thunder.

" 'It's today', I thought. 'He's going or has he gone yet?' I felt it so surely that it was in the floor beneath my feet as I got out of bed and in the air around me as I went downstairs.

"I felt numb, suspended in time, as I went through the motions of life. At nine I phoned my mum and told her I wasn't going to take Laird to his swimming lesson that morning. 'What's going on?' she said. 'You sound so quiet. Oz is home tomorrow, you should be happy'.

"I paused. 'He's not coming home, Mum, I know it'. "

Oz was killed, defusing a bomb, on Halloween while Christina was walking in the woods gathering her thoughts.

At the exact moment he died she wept uncontrollably.

Later in her book Christina reveals more spiritual happenings. She tells how Oz's spirit communicated with her through the spiritualist mum of a friend.

She writes what the spiritualist said: "He's saying, 'Coffee, white, one  man-up'. Oh, and what an awful taste, it's something like liquorice. What is that?' I smiled. 'His liquorice rollies, the menthol tips, he always smoked them. And that's how he talked'. She had his intonation exactly right.

"She always passes on an Oz message in his distinctive style.

"And it helps me to keep going and keeps me grounded."

pages.headline: CPR helped me save lives. Everyone should learn it
pages.teaser: LORD Robert Winston backs Sun campaign for CPR to be taught in British schools
pages.articlebody:
ONE of the world's most respected doctors and scientists is backing The Sun's campaign for all schoolchildren to be taught basic life-saving skills.

Here, he tells us why even more Sun readers should add their names to our petition.

I HAVE resuscitated collapsed colleagues on five separate occasions in the House of Lords.

This was always after they had just completed a speech.

Speaking in that frightening chamber is very stressful.

It is filled with people with extraordinary expertise.

Someone listening will always seem to know more about the subject than the person speaking.

So when a peer gets up to speak, his or her pulse rate frequently rises dramatically.

I am willing to bet that their blood pressure also rises by around 30 per cent.

To sign The Sun-backed British Heart Foundation petition, click here

So it isn't surprising that, when finished, some members simply keel over. Sometimes they literally just faint. But occasionally, they have a cardiac arrest.

As one of a few doctors there when I joined the Lords 17 years ago, I was appalled how poor were the arrangements for these sudden, terrifying emergencies.

The attendant staff had often been trained in mouth-to-mouth and cardiac resuscitation, but there was no defibrillator anywhere in Parliament. This piece of kit is a life-saver.

When its electrodes are applied across the chest, its sudden pulse of high voltage electricity can jolt the heart back into a normal rhythmic beat. It's a clever device because its detector only allows an electric shock if the collapsed patient has had a cardiac arrest or a fatal change of heart rhythm.

So it is safe and exceptionally easy to use by any layman with minimal training.

Yet when I tried to persuade the authorities in Parliament to obtain one of these portable machines (they are not expensive) officials in both Houses refused. Their excuses were shameful.

One official argued that we could not have a defibrillator as it would cause a problem if a tourist collapsed in the gallery  should we be obliged to offer resuscitation to a member of the public? It was suggested there might be legal consequences if it were used or not used. Four years later, an elderly peer collapsed right after speaking. There were no doctors present in the chamber and he died.

Only then, reluctantly, was a defibrillator installed, and since then at least two lives have been saved. Cardiac arrest is extremely common yet it can be correctable. Clearly, it would help if everybody were trained in external cardiac massage, for example in schools. This knowledge would save some lives.

But a clever defibrillator is a different matter. It is astonishing that so many public buildings do not have them readily available.

Those first few seconds after a cardiac emergency are critical and we must be prepared.

pages.teaser: BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity
pages.byline: By EMMA LITTLE, Health Editor and DANIEL JONES, Consumer Editor
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S biggest brands are going on a "diet"  slashing their calorie count as part of a war on obesity.

The number of calories in certain products made by soft drinks giant Coca-Cola will be cut by 30 per cent by 2014.

It will also pump more cash into marketing Diet Coke and Coca-Cola Zero, which contain no sugar, and increase their availability.

Mars bars will be cut from 300 calories to 250, and super-size "Grab Bags" of Walkers crisps, containing 263 calories, will be phased out and replaced with 185-calorie packs.

The move aims to take FIVE BILLION calories a day off Britain's national food and drink intake. More than two-thirds of adults and one in three 11-year-olds are now overweight or obese. Food manufacturers, supermarkets, pubs and caterers joined with the Department of Health yesterday to announce the "Responsibility Deal".

Producers including Hovis and Mr Kipling will slash calorie counts by 30 per cent across a third of their ranges.

Supermarkets will expand their healthy meal ranges and sandwich chain Subway will include five low-fat subs in its £3 lunch offer. Health Secretary Andrew Lansley hailed the plan as "a great step in the right direction," adding: "We all have a role to play."

Diet expert Dr Susan Jebb, of Cambridge University, said: "This programme is vital to tackle obesity. It's a very encouraging start, but it will take time to change the nation's eating habits."

STEPHANIE FOX has something she'd like to get off her chest... her back-breaking, all-natural, size 32K boobs are casting a shadow over her life.

The 21-year-old can't get a boyfriend, can't find clothes to fit and can't even walk down the street without getting an earful of abuse.

Men don't look her in the eye. Girls assume she is a porn star. Then there's the back pain.

She says: "Lots of women want big boobs but it's actually a total nightmare.

"The only men I attract are the sleazy type. It's rare that a guy looks me in the face when talking to me.

"Guys will flat-out stare and try all the cheesy chat-up lines. And a lot of the time they want their picture taken with them. Not me  them."

She adds: "Sometimes it can be a bit scary. A few blokes will try to get really hands-on. When I'm out with my male friends they'll usually circle round me. They're my bodyguards."

Stephanie doesn't fare much better with other girls. She says: "Women assume my boobs are fake  they look at me like I'm a porn star. It's older women who always comment on them.

"They'll tut and shake their heads as they walk past me in the street. I can hear them saying, 'They're so fake', and, 'Look at her flaunting them'.

"I try to smile through it. I know they're real but sometimes it can be hurtful.

"I've developed a way of walking so my boobs bounce up and down and people can see they're real. It looks like I'm walking on the moon.

"Women can get quite jealous  that's probably why I have more male friends."

But meeting the right guy is difficult. Glasgow girl Stephanie says: "I broke up with my ex in 2010. He couldn't handle all the attention I get and became insanely jealous.

"When we were out he'd get mad when other guys checked me out. I tried telling him it couldn't be helped  he knew what he was getting into."

Stephanie has seen a few men since the split but no one special has caught her eye.

She says: "They become too obsessed with my boobs, it's all they think about. It's hard to find a guy to see past them.

"A lot of blokes are just after me for the status of it, they see it as just another notch on the bedpost.

"I want my boyfriend to see me for me, I'm more than just a pair of boobs. I'm a laid back and a down-to-earth girl and I love to have a laugh." Stephanie's boobs proved something of an overnight sensation when she was just 12.

She recalls: "It was so weird. I was a total cheeseboard then one day I woke up with a C cup. It was really annoying because I loved PE and sport.

"I was really into hurdles and running but my boobs started to restrict me. And as I got bigger, it was harder to find a sports bra."

During one family holiday in America Stephanie and her mum Josie, 51, went in search of one that would fit.

She recalls: "We tried this lingerie shop to get a measurement. I was 19 and about a 30J at that point.

"The staff couldn't believe it. Instead of measuring me they just kept calling more and more staff members out of the back to stare at them."

Stephanie adds: "Finding a bikini is atrocious. Nothing fits me so I have to buy separates. "I'll buy a size 12 for my lower half and a 20 for my top half  but even that's too small and they'll be spilling out all over the place. I also get serious back pain.

"Exercise is a nightmare. To do any exercise I have to wear a bra then a sports bra on top.

"I'll go to my local gym and I just get stared at. Gym clothes are quite tight so the guys will full-on stare."

Stephanie doesn't know how she got her huge boobs  though there is something in her family genes.

She says: "My mum does have big boobs but she's probably more of a DD or an E. But my sister Morena has normal-sized breasts.

"Whenever I visit her she'll say, 'God, Stephanie, can you give me some of your boobs!'"

She adds: "I think my dad and older brothers found it awkward when I blossomed. They didn't like men checking me out on the beach. We went on holiday to Italy last year. We went to a water park and I was getting a lot of male attention. Wives were whacking their husbands over the head for staring."

Stephanie works in her parents' fancy dress shop, where she is able to stitch her clothes to fit. She says: "If I don't adjust tops they swamp me or I just look huge. So I've become quite the seamstress."

As for the future, Stephanie plans to start her own business and says: "I know it sounds weird but I'd love to run my own corn on the cob stall.

"I saw a stall selling sweetcorn when I was 15 and ever since, that's what I've wanted to do. You can have butter and pepper on it and things like that  it would be pretty cool."

And despite all the aggro she gets over her shape, on balance she wouldn't want to downsize.

She says: "A part of me loves the attention. They're a great talking point and I get to meet a lot of people. But the downsides probably outweigh that one positive.

"And even the attention can be a double-edged sword. Some days I just don't want to be stared at."

GOLDEN oldie Ryan Giggs has set himself a target of playing 1000 games for Manchester United.

The 38-year-old has chalked up a record 904 appearances for the club since making his debut 22 years ago.

Since then he has won 12 Premier League titles, four FA Cups, three League Cups, two Champions Leagues, one Super Cup, an Intercontinental Cup and a FIFA Club World Cup.

The Wales legend penned a new one-year extension to his Old Trafford deal last month.

And he is adamant he will not make the same mistake as team-mate Paul Scholes  who retired last summer only to make a dramatic comeback in January.

Giggs said: "It's nice to have played 900 games for Manchester United  that's special.

"But I don't look too far into the future  I just try and enjoy the moment and do my best.

"If it's to be 10 more games then so be it. If it's to be 100 more games then that would be great."

Giggs has played in 20 of United's 30 Premier League matches so far this season.

And the influence he and Scholes have had on the team has been a key factor in United overhauling neighbours City at the top of the Premier League.

But Giggs maintains a punishing fitness regime is the main reason he is still able to keep pace with more youthful team-mates like Phil Jones and Danny Welbeck.

He added: "Yoga has definitely helped me. It helps me with training because it gives me the flexibility and the strength to not only play games but train every day.

"I rarely miss a training session even if I do a little bit less than the younger players.

"You have to change your way of thinking. I was a quick player when I was younger but now I'm not as quick.

"So you have to use your intelligence and experience on the pitch to adapt your game and change your game  which I have done."

However, Giggs admits he does have one eye on what he will be doing once his playing days are over.

And he would be interested in following a similar path into management as the one Pep Guardiola took on his way to taking charge of Barcelona.

Speaking to Gazzetta Dello Sport, Giggs said: "At the moment I'm focused on playing but I will be involved in football afterwards.

"I've done my coaching badges and done all I can to prepare myself for life after football.

"But to manage a team like Manchester United?

"Guardiola's done it at Barcelona but even he was the coach of their 'B' team for a couple of years.

"He had a little bit of experience managing so we'll have to see.

"My goal when I was younger was to play for Manchester United just once.

"But then after that you get greedy. You want to be in the team all the time. Then you want to score goals.

"Then you get really greedy  you want to win trophies and then you win more trophies.

"All these things have happened to me  I realised my dream and at 38 I'm still living my dream. You can't ask for much more."

pages.subdeck: SWANN SONG ... Graeme Swann celebrates taking the wicket of Mahela Jayawardene
pages.headline: Swann on song but batsmen fail again
pages.teaser: GRAEME SWANN led England's fightback with the ball but the tourists' suffered another spin-induced batting collapse
pages.articlebody:
GRAEME SWANN led England's fightback back with the ball but their day will be remembered for another spin-induced batting collapse.

Sri Lanka closed on 84-5 in their second innings, a lead of 209, with Swann taking 4-28 as 17 wickets fell on day two of the first Test in Galle.

But the fact the hosts were even out in the middle again told the story of another poor England batting display.

Rangana Herath did the damage with 6-74 as England were skittled for just 193 on a pitch, and against an attack, where 400 should have been in their sights.

Only Ian Bell  who himself failed against spin in Pakistan  showed any resistance and top-scored with 52.

England's last four batsmen chipped in with a combined 88, including a 46-run last-wicket stand, to give the tourists' top order food for thought.

Sri Lanka resumed their first innings on 289-8 this morning and added 29 with Mahela Jayawardene the last man to fall to Jimmy Anderson for a mammoth 180.

Anderson also dismissed Chanaka Welegedara to register his 12th five-wicket haul in Tests and become the first English seamer to pick up a five-for in Sri Lanka.

The tourists will have been targeting a first-innings lead but the ever reliable Alistair Cook prodded forward to a Welegedara inswinger and was lbw for nought.

Andrew Strauss and Jonathan Trott began positively until England's first sight of spin in the ninth over.

Trott fell first to Herath in baffling fashion, stumped after letting a full toss disappear between bat and pad.

He then collided with wicketkeeper Prasanna Jayawardene and collapsed dramatically before departing in a daze.

Strauss was gone for 26 just 13 balls later, given lbw on review attempting a pre-meditated sweep against Herath.

Bell, the only batsman without a half-century on tour, began well against Herath to take England to 57-3 at lunch and he continued to attack after the break.

Kevin Pietersen also attempted to be positive but with dire results.

He aimed a flashy drive at his first ball of the session but, with a little movement off the pitch, succeeded only in inside edging into the stumps for three.

England's woes continued as Matt Prior, promoted to number six, lasted just seven deliveries before becoming Herath's third victim when he was pinned in front of middle stump.

He reviewed the decision in hope more than expectation and was duly on his way for seven.

Debutant Samit Patel came in with the score on 72-5 and mustered just two singles before he mimicked Prior's dismissal, lbw on the back foot against Herath.

While Bell scored steadily, No8 Stuart Broad boosted England's tally with a flurry of boundaries off Suranga Lakmal.

But Herath halted Broad's counterpunching cameo at 28 from 15 balls when he fell lbw on the sweep.

Graeme Swann followed Broad's lead, finding the ropes six times on his way to 24 before Tillakaratne Dilshan's reaction catch at short mid-wicket handed Suraj Randiv a first success.

England's chances of a competitive total looked to have ended when Bell was bowled by a good ball from Herath for 52.

Yet Anderson (23no) and Monty Panesar (13) added another 36 for the last wicket before the latter was leg before to Randiv.

Having already toiled in the Galle heat for just shy of 100 overs, England's bowlers will not have been relishing the prospect of another day out in the sun.

But they needed to deliver if England were to have any chance in the game and Broad bowled Dilshan for a duck in the second over.

Swann cleaned up fellow opener Lahiru Thirimanne for six and then took the prized wicket of first-innings centurion Jayawaderne, caught by Anderson at slip for just five.

Sri Lanka were 14-3 and England suddenly had a sniff. Kumar Sangakkara and Thilan Samaraweera led something of a recovery before the former also fell to Swann for 14.

Samaraweera pushed the hosts towards a 200-run lead but missed another Swann twirler and was stumped by Prior for 36.

Dinesh Chandimal was 17 not out at stumps and with England's batting so fragile, Sri Lanka will be forgiven for thinking they have almost built a match-winning lead already.

IAN BELL admits England's batsmen have let their bowlers down again.

The tourists were skittled for 193 on day two against Sri Lanka and have now been rolled over for less than 200 five times in seven innings this year.

The bowlers, in particular Graeme Swann, got England back in the hunt, reducing the hosts to 84-5 after keeping them to just 318 in the first innings.

And Bell, who top-scored with 52, accepts the performances have simply not been good enough from England's top order.

He said: "It's a real shame and it's not through lack of effort but it's disappointing not to back up our bowler.

"We definitely let them down, no doubt. The bowlers will know it's not through a lack of preparation, sometimes it just happens like that.

"Our bowlers have been outstanding again for the fourth Test this winter.

"What we wanted to do was to give those bowlers a good rest, a bit like we did in Australia.

"If you give them a day and a half relaxing they're going to come out hard again. In a way we let them down not to give them that time."

Spin was again the issue for England today in Galle with Rangana Herath picking up six wickets and Surag Randiv two.

And having been bamboozled by Saeed Ajmal and Abdur Rehman in the United Arab Emirates, Bell acknowledges more hard work is needed to improve against slow bowling.

He added: "We're all trying to get better at playing spin. We all know we have to get better at playing in the sub-continent.

"It's a long-term goal and it isn't going to just happen overnight.

"The score doesn't lie, to get bowled out again for under 200 isn't great, but as a unit we're working very hard."

The written judgment should be publish by Friday.

Television footage did not capture the bite, but Ferris and some of his team-mates complained to referee Nigel Owens in the immediate aftermath.

Hartley responded: "I am disappointed by the result and I will wait for the written judgment as to how the panel came to their conclusion.

"I now have to put it behind me and focus on supporting Saints in training and off the field."

The independent Six Nations committee examined the evidence and listened to Hartley, his legal representative, Northampton director of rugby Jim Mallinder, England forwards coach Graham Rowntree and Ferris via a video link.

The offence was found to have contravened IRB Law 10.4 (m) "acts contrary to good sportsmanship".

The 26-year-old can resume playing from May 14 and will only play for Saints again this season if they reach the Premiership final 12 days later.

pages.articlebody:
ROMAN ABRAMOVICH has spent the last nine years chasing the Champions League trophy.

He has spent millions and changed numerous managers in his pursuit, so to not even qualify for the tournament next season would be catastrophic  and a complete embarrassment.

I see Chelsea beating Benfica over the two legs in their Champions League quarter-final.

As I said last week, neither Milan or Barcelona would fancy playing a Chelsea team inspired by an in-form Fernando Torres.

But, right now, I still think Chelsea could struggle to reach the final.

If Chelsea triumph in Munich on May 19, it would be the result of the century when you consider everything that has happened at the west London club over these last few months.

Instead, I think they will have to sort out their league form just to qualify for next season's Champions League.

Fair play to Petr Cech for being honest and admitting it would be "a lost season" if Chelsea are not in the competition next term.

We are always hearing players at big clubs coming out with the same old predictable lines, so I have great respect for Cech being honest.

He is right as Chelsea could face numerous problems if they fail to reach the Champions League.

It may be easy to entice players with a combination of big money and likely success.

Manchester City have the cash and now they can promise new signings the chance of likely silverware.

Chelsea have been in a similar situation over the years as they have paid huge sums to players who have also known they are guaranteed matches on the biggest stage in Europe.

So Chelsea will find themselves in an unusual position come the summer if they finish outside the top four.

The only reward for players going to Stamford Bridge would be big bucks  and that is not always enough.

Also, you get a certain type of top-class player who is prepared to sacrifice ambition in terms of not playing in the Champions League.

So everyone at Stamford Bridge could be facing their worst nightmare.

Chelsea will still be confident of catching Spurs because Harry Redknapp's side have gone off the boil.

The 0-0 draw with Chelsea made it five League games without a win so it's also testing times for Tottenham.

This is Redknapp's biggest battle since he took over at Spurs.

I believe Spurs have to beat Bolton in the FA Cup tonight and see off Swansea on Sunday to keep their season alive.

Tottenham do not have the experience at this stage of the season and this could be crucial in the battle for fourth.

When you look at Tottenham's impressive season  and they have played some outstanding football  it would be disastrous for Spurs to end up in a Europa League spot.

Maybe it is no coincidence that Tottenham's slump is at the same time as Redknapp (left) has emerged as an England target.

There is no way that Harry has taken his eye off the ball despite the interest in him taking over for Euro 2012.

Maybe other people within the team have become unsettled by the speculation.

For Harry's sake, I hope he can turn the season around. He deserves it.

It will be a tough game against Bolton at White Hart Lane after what happened in the first match. But it is terrific that Fabrice Muamba is making a steady recovery so I'm not sure the match will be as difficult for the players as some people suggest.

Yet, incredibly, Chelsea and Spurs are not the only teams to be struggling in this remarkable end to the season.

Kenny Dalglish is fortunate he has won a cup this season. Because all that is keeping him in a job is the Carling Cup and his reputation.

Liverpool have splashed out lots of money yet they could soon be below Swansea and Norwich in the table if they keep failing to pick up decent results.

Stoke are only four points behind and they are 12th in the Premier League.

Dalglish has spent all this cash yet there is not a great deal of quality within the squad.

I can see all his enthusiasm on the sidelines but something is not right. Something has to change.

Meanwhile, Arsenal keep on winning. I'm not sure anyone would have predicted the season would finish like this.

ALAN PARDEW hopes Newcastle's versatility will help them qualify for Europe.

The Toon boss has been forced to put square pegs in round holes in recent weeks, with winger Jonas Gutierrez filling in at left-back and centre-midfield and James Perch filling in in numerous positions.

But such is the flexibility in Pardew's squad, the Magpies have managed back-to-back wins against Norwich and West Brom and are within touching distance of qualification for the Europa League.

Pardew said: "You have to remember that when you have had success, teams are going to come and nullify you and start working on ways to beat you, and you have got to keep asking different questions.

"Yohan Cabaye and Jonas had different roles last week, and they could have different roles again.

"But their application and attitude to them has been first-class, and that's why Jonas at left-back got man of the match against Norwich, because he attacked the job that was at hand.

"If my players do that and take that as a lesson, then we are going to be okay."

Star midfielder Cheick Tiote was sidelined for the win over the Baggies and has been missing for large parts of the season due to injury and Ivory Coast's African Cup of Nations campaign.

But Pardew reckons the Toon have fared well in Tiote's absence.

He said: "We have won without Cheick for the last two weekends, and we won without him when he was away at the African Nations Cup.

"Actually, since he has come back, we haven't had great results with Cheick.

"I am not saying that as a negative because he is a massive player for us, but we can cope without him."

Drogba is likely to be on the bench tonight and Blues' ex-Benfica star David Luiz said: "He wouldn't disrespect a team like that."

pages.subdeck: URGENT NEED ... Lampard says Chelsea need more passion
pages.headline: Lampard and Di Matteo disagree
pages.teaser: BOSS Di Matteo says Blues are good enough  even if ace Lampard publicly doubts it
pages.articlebody:
ROBERTO DI MATTEO reckons Chelsea are in good shape  even if his own midfield star Frank Lampard disagrees.

But both the Blues interim boss and the veteran campaigner, 33, are united in their drive to knock Benfica out of the Champions League.

The first leg of the quarter-final takes place in Lisbon's Estadio Da Luz tonight  with the lead up to the game dominated by Lampard's opinions and what Di Matteo thought of them.

Lampard told Chelsea's own TV station that the Blues were not as good as they once were and that their position of fifth in the league was not good enough.

He also argued they had lost their aura of invincibility at Stamford Bridge after what he felt was a poor display in the 0-0 draw at home to Spurs last Saturday.

And he called on Chelsea to produce in Europe again and perform like they did to get through the last round where they overturned a 3-1 first-leg deficit against Napoli to win the second-leg 4-1.

Lampard said: "The fixtures and where we are in the table doesn't lie  we're not as good as we used to be.

"We used to have a fortress and, for whatever reason, we're just not doing it.

"It's something we must all put right.

"I don't think we were at it enough against Tottenham.

"We had to play more with the urgency we showed against Napoli. Against Tottenham, we didn't really do enough to lift the fans.

"We had the high of Napoli, then we got beaten by Manchester City and now we need to up it again.

"Chelsea should be in the top four. No disrespect to the other top-five clubs but, with the ability we have, we should be in there.

"It is far from over. There is no point being downbeat about it at the minute.

"It's five points and the gap has been bigger than that.

"It's up to us now to get ourselves right for Benfica and the league games coming up."

Chelsea chairman Bruce Buck and chief executive Ron Gourlay looked on as Di Matteo responded  just as they observed Andre Villas Boas in Napoli not long before he was sacked.

And Di Matteo was keen to paint a positive picture of life under his management for the bosses who report to owner Roman Abramovich.

He said: "We've had a difficult season. The numbers say that, so there is no point in denying it.

"But we have quality in this team and many good players. I still think this Chelsea team is a very good team.

"Chelsea used to be in the top two or top three, at least.

"So it's been hard for us, domestically.

"But we're in the semi-finals of a domestic cup, and in the quarter-finals of the Champions League.

"I have faith in this team. They've shown they can play at high intensity at a high level, so I'm looking forward to doing that again here.

"I am positive about the team, but my players are positive too.

"We have great belief in our abilities. That's what we're going to try and express.

"In the Premier League we are a bit behind in terms of points, but internationally and domestically we are in a good position in the cups.

"If we had a few more points in the Premier League, then we wouldn't be talking like this.

"It's a very fine line between success and failure.

"This team has all the ability to play a very good game and show the qualities these players have."

"We are scoring goals and creating chances.

"We're averaging more than two a game in the matches I've had in charge. We also look strong and solid. I don't see a problem there.

"I'm quite confident about my team, to be honest. Everybody seems to have an opinion, and they have that right, but I disagree.

"I believe in my team, my squad, my players. I don't think we're weak, not at all.

"We have, still, many games to play in the Premier League to reach fourth, and two games in the quarter-finals of the Champions League. It looked a little gloomier two weeks ago, so we're pleased to be here."

On the team plane out to Portugal were former Chelsea chief executive Peter Kenyon, still "a friend" of the club and Queen drummer Roger Taylor, a Blues fan.

It must be hoped that, come the conclusion of this quarter-final, it is not a case of "Another One Bites the Dust."

pages.articlebody:
GOALKEEPER  CITY

DURING the early weeks of the season it was no contest as David De Gea struggled to find his feet in English football and Joe Hart looked in prime form.

United's Spanish keeper has closed the gap over the last few weeks but England's No 1 down at the Etihad still edges it.

DEFENCE  UNITED

CITY'S Europa League defeat in Lisbon has proved costly with first-choice pairing Joleon Lescott and Vincent Kompany both injured and yet to return.

United struggled initially after Nemanja Vidic was crocked but have coped well on the whole and look to have more options.

MIDFIELD  CITY

NO matter what Patrick Vieira says, bringing back Paul Scholes has proved to be inspired. He allows Alex Ferguson to shuffle his pack as he did last night.

City's midfield looked unstoppable at the start of the season but key men like Yaya Toure and David Silva are feeling the pace.

ATTACK  UNITED

ROBERTO MANCINI almost has an embarrassment of riches with Carlos Tevez back. But the goals have dried up for Mario Balotelli and Edin Dzeko, leaving the onus on Sergio Aguero.

Fergie does not have the same options but he does have Rooney hitting his straps.

MANAGER  UNITED

ONLY one winner here. Fergie's 12 Premier League titles makes him pretty much untouchable and he has largely kept his cool throughout.

Mancini won titles in Italy but it is fair to say he never had anyone quite like the veteran Scot breathing down his neck.

pages.subdeck: THOUGHTFUL ... Owen Coyle
pages.headline: Cheers, Harry
pages.teaser: BUT the Bolton boss plans to repay him by ending Tottenham's Wembley dream
pages.articlebody:
OWEN COYLE has thanked Harry Redknapp for the outstanding support he showed during Fabrice Muamba's fight for life.

But the Bolton boss plans to repay him by ending Tottenham's Wembley dream at White Hart Lane tonight.

Coyle revealed the Spurs chief has been ringing him every day in the aftermath of midfielder Muamba's cardiac arrest. He is looking forward to showing his gratitude to Redknapp  but insists his team are going to North London to earn an FA Cup semi-final place.

The original tie was abandoned in horrific circumstances 10 days ago as Muamba collapsed 41 minutes into the game.

Coyle said: "It doesn't surprise me because I know the man he is anyway, but I've spoken to Harry two or three times a day since last week.

"That was while I was down there. But even when I came back and we both had games to prepare for, I spoke to him each day. That just sums up the man he is.

"He didn't have to be phoning two or three times a day for an update, but he had genuine concern and goodwill.

"From Daniel Levy as chairman all the way through the club, Tottenham Hotspur have been truly outstanding."

Coyle will lead a delegation from Wanderers to the London Chest Hospital today to visit Muamba, 23, who remains in a serious condition.

Two players are likely to go, with his close friends David Wheater, Gretar Steinsson and Sam Ricketts particularly keen to see him.

Coyle said: "There'll be a small representation at the family's request to come and see Fabrice.

"Then they can filter the news back to the lads  hopefully that he is continuing to improve. We'll try to progress to the semi-final. It's going to be emotional but I'll pick a team that can win."

Ricketts revealed Bolton's stars suffered with sickness and flashbacks after Muamba's collapse.

Coyle added: "I'll speak to them all and check they are ready to play. But we'll probably be very close to the team that took the field last time."

Coyle was buoyed by news Muamba had watched his team's 2-1 victory over Blackburn on Match of the Day.

He said: "He was able to watch it on Sunday. I'm led to believe he fell asleep when it was 2-0  I don't know if he still thinks we won 2-0.

"For those of us who were there on that Saturday night, to think that a week later he could sit up and watch some of that game is remarkable."

pages.subdeck: RISING STAR ... Ayrton Senna steers his Toleman TG-184-2 at the 1984 Monaco Grand Prix in his F1 debut season
pages.headline: Ayrton Senna's Formula One Toleman expected to raise £750,000
pages.teaser: A 1984 Toleman raced by Formula One legend Ayrton Senna is expected to raise £750,000 at a Silverstone auction
pages.articlebody:
A 1984 Toleman raced by Formula One legend Ayrton Senna is expected to raise £750,000 at a Silverstone auction.

What is probably the ultimate piece of F1 memorabilia will be available at The Spring Sale hosted by Silverstone Auctions on May 16.

Senna made his F1 debut in the Toleman TG184-2 in the 1984 season and announced his arrival with a stunning drive in a rain-affected Monaco Grand Prix.

Despite starting 13th on the grid, the future three-time world champion seemed untroubled by the near flooding of the famous street circuit to power through the field into second place.

Catching leader Alain Prost at an incredible four seconds a lap, Senna looked destined to claim his first win but with the weather deteriorating fast race organisers cancelled the event after 31 laps.

Senna was awarded second place and all drivers were given half the normal allocation of points due to the race being halted.

But it was the first giant step in the F1 career of a Brazilian whose talent was to wow every motorsport fan for a decade until his death at Imola in 1994.

In this car Senna went on to claim third place in the British Grand Prix and seventh in Canada and he ended his debut season ninth in the drivers' championship.

Nick Whale, managing director of Silverstone Auctions, said: "Senna mania is reaching fever pitch and rightly so as he's considered by many as the greatest F1 driver we've ever seen.

"This will be one of the star attractions at the sale as it's a very rare chance to own a much sought after piece of motorsport and Ayrton Senna history."

The Toleman TG184-2 produces 650bhp from a 1.5-litre turbo-charged engine coupled with a Hewland 5-speed manual gearbox.

In 1985, Chassis TG184-2 was passed by Toleman to Grand Prix driver Stefan Johansson in lieu of salary.

The former Ferrari driver kept the iconic motor until 1994 when it was acquired by the present owner.

According to Silverstone Auctions, the car is in excellent condition and has not needed restoration.

pages.subdeck: TROUBLES ... Bradford Bulls are facing meltdown
pages.headline: Bradford Bulls hit by financial crisis
pages.teaser: BRADFORD BULLS need to raise £500,000 in just 10 DAYS or they will go bust
pages.articlebody:
BRADFORD BULLS need to raise £500,000 in just 10 DAYS or they will go bust.

The Super League club are hoping to raise £1million in donations from supporters and sponsors.

Bulls chairman Peter Hood revealed they were dealt a blow last week when the Royal Bank of Scotland cut their overdraft facility.

That has left the club with "no cash" according to Hood.

He said: "I don't think the situation could be more critical.

"We've got to generate a significant sum to survive and we're doing everything we can to achieve that.

"If we haven't got cash, then we can't stay alive and if we can't stay alive then we can't fulfil our fixtures. It's that serious."

The Bulls need to raise £500,000 by next Friday to stave off the threat of collapse.

And they have written to every season-ticket holder, member and sponsor in a desperate plea for funds.

The RFL say they are aware of the crisis and are backing the club's survival bid.

RFL director of standards and licensing Blake Solly said: "The RFL would urge everyone who cares about Bradford Bulls to support the pledge scheme.

"We have been providing and continue to provide Bradford Bulls with all the practical support we can to help the club through their current financial difficulties."

pages.subdeck: RED-DY FOR ACTION ... All smiles at the 12 Hours of Sebring 2012
pages.headline: Jules finds a gem in the Sun-shine
pages.teaser: PICTURE SPECIAL: SEE the 60th anniversary of the annual endurance race through the lens of Juliet Lemon
pages.articlebody:
SUN snapper Juliet Lemon is just back from an extended trip to the US of A  during which she took in the first classic sportscar race of the season, the 12 Hours of Sebring.

And here's a terrific slideshow in which our Jules will give you a taste of her fun in the Florida sun, as the annual endurance race celebrated its 60th anniversary.

She hung out for much of the time with the Sun-backed Strakka Racing team, who recorded an encouraging top 10 finish in their first race with their new HPD-Honda Le Mans car.

And she said: "It was great to see the Strakka guys with all their Sun logos on their racesuits, caps and crash helmets.

"The whole team worked sooooo hard but also managed to add a touch of glamour to the proceedings with a pretty pair of Sun girls.

"I reckon they've got the right idea on how to go racing."

There were a whole lot of other sights and sounds on offer.

And Juliet said: "The buzz was immense and I even managed to enjoy it while working flat-out for 22 hours on race day.

"I loved the craziness of the paddock as fans hunted down stars and cars, some even zooming around in hired golf buggies.

"I had a fun brush with celebrity myself as I got to rub shoulders with Patrick Dempsey in the Lotus garage and then again on the starting grid."

Juliet, who was also taking shots for the Endurance Sportscar website, added: "There was a wild, full-on party atmosphere all around the circuit with BBQs and beer outside those huge campervans in which Americans seem to pack everything but the kitchen sink.

"Actually, come to think of it, some of them DID bring the kitchen sink!

"Healthy food was hard to find  not a surprise in the US, I guess.

"But, heck, there was plenty of tequila flowing as the booze brand Patron was one of the main sponsors. So it wasn't all bad!"

Juliet said she would recommend Sebring, the opening round of the World Endurance Championship, to any Sun readers looking to try a race with a difference.

And combining it with a winter holiday in Florida seems like a decent idea.

Jules added: "I worked really hard for days on end. So it was only fair that I rewarded myself with a short stay in Miami. It's such a great city for partying!"
